II. And be it enacted, That if any Person not qualified as aforesaid, shall nevertheless presume to act as a Trustee, every such Person, shall for every such acting, forfeit the Sum of Twenty Pounds Sreriing, besides the Expence ol Prosecution, to be recovered by Complaint in a summary Way, at the Suit of any Heritor of the said County, before the Justices of the Peace at their Quarter Seffior.s, or before the Sheriffs Depute or Substitute of Pertbshire-, which Penalty shall be paid to the Trustees aforesaid, to be applied by them for repairing the said Roads, and in case any such Complaint shall be brought, the Proof of Qualification shall lie upon the Person complained of.

III. And be it enacted, That if any of the said Trustees shall accept or hold any Place of Profit arising out of this Act, by reason of any T0U9 or Duties hereby granted, he shall be incapable of acting as a Trustee during his Enjoyment of such Place of Profit; and that no Victualler or Retailer of Beer, Ale, or Spirituous Liquors shall be capable of holding or enjoying any Office of Trust, Profit, or Collection under this Act.

IV. And be it enacted, That the said Trustees, or any Three or more of them, shall hold their first stated or General Meeting by virtue of this Act, on the Fourth Monday after the passing of this Act, or as fbon thereafter as conveniently may be at Perth, and their Second stated General Meeting on the Day on which the next Michaelmas Meeting of the Freeholders of the said County of Perth is held, and shall thereafter hold Two general stated Meetings at Perth in each Yejr during the Continuance of this Act, one upon the Day on which the Commissioners of Supply shall meet for assessing the Land Tax on the said County, and the other upon the Day of the Michaelmas Meeting of Freeholders of the said Country, with Power to the said Trustees, or Majority of tholir present at any of the said stated or general Meetings, to adjourn to fuefi other Time and Place as they shall think convenient, with Power to name a Committee of their Number, being Heritors of the respectivs Parishes through which the Roads pass, or Creditors on the said Roads to the Extent of One hundred Pounds Sterling, to have the more immediate Care and Management of particular Parts of the said Roads, ar.j to give their Committees, (whereof Three to be a Quorum,) such In-flruftions and Powers as they shall think fit and expedient, not being inconsistent with the Powers by this Act given.

VII. VIII. And be it further enacted, That the Quorum of the Trustees necessary to do Business in General Meetings shall be three; but if only one, or any Number less than three shall be present at any of the stated, or other general Meetings, such Trustee or Trustees shall have Power to adjourn the Meeting; and in that Cafe, Notice shall be given of the Day, Place, and Purpose of such adjourned Meeting, by two several Advertisements, in some Newspaper published at Perth, and in default thereof in some Newspaper published in Edinburgh; the first of such Advertisements being at ieaft fourteen Days before the Day of such adjourned Meeting; and the Clerk of the said Trustees shall have Power, and he is hereby required, when directed, by a Writing under the Hands of any two or more Trustees, to call, at any Time, a General Meeting, giving the like previous Notice of the Time, Place, and Purpose of the Meeting; and at such Meetings no Business shall be entered or decided upon, other than what is specified in the Notice given as aforesaid; and it shall not be in the Power of any stated or General Meeting to relcind, alter, or vary the Determination of any former stated or General Meeting, unless previous Notice of the Intention of so doing, and the Time and Place of the Meeting, be given by Advertisements in such Newspaper as aforesaid; and at all their Meetings the Trustees present shall defray their own Expences.

IX. And be it enacted, That it shall be in the Power of the Convener or Prefes of any Committee, named by any General Meeting, to call, at any Time, a Meeting of such Committee, at any Place within any Parish in which any Part of the District of Road committed to the Charge of such Committee shall be fuuated, on giving Notice, in Writing, at the usual Place of Residence of each Member of such Committee, if within any Parish of such District, at least eight Days before the Day of such Meeting.

For every Drove of Oxen, or neat Cattle, the Sum of two Shillings Sterling per Score, and so in proportion for any greater or smaller Number:

For every Drove of Calves, Hogs, Sheep, Lambs, or Goats, the Sum of one Shilling Sterling per Score, and so in proportion for any greater or smaller Number; and the said Trustees shall cause a Table of the Tolls to be printed and affixed upon, or near each Turnpike Gate, or . XXVII. XXVIII. And be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said Trustees, at their first, or any subsequent general Meeting, to inquire into, and ascertain what Lands in the Neighbourhood of the said Roada will be benefited by the said Roads, and to make up a Schedule thereof, (a Copy of which Schedule shall be delivered to each Proprietor of Lands contained in such Schedule, either personally, or left at his ordinary Dwelling Place one Calendar Month at lead, previous to any Asseirment founded thereon, as herein after-mentioned being made); and it shall and may be lawful for any such Proprietor or Proprietors, if he, she, or they, shall think himself, herself, or themselves aggrieved, by the Manner of making up such Schedule, to apply for Redress to the Sheriff Depute, or Substitute, of the County of Perth, or to the Court of Session, at any Time within three Months after such Schedule shall have been so delivered as aforesaid, but not afterwards; and if no Application for Redress shall have been made within the said three Months, the said Schedule shall not afterwards be liable to be altered; but it shall be lawful to the said Trustees at the End of such three Months, to assess upon the Lands contained in such Schedule, in proportion to their Valuation in the Cess-Books of the County of Perth, the Amount of theefiimated or contrafted Expence, of making the said Roads and building the said Bridges; which Assessment ffiail be levied at the same Time with, and in the same Manner at the Land Tax is levied; and which Assessment shall be and continue a Lien upon the Tolls by this Act granted; and the said Trustees are hereby required to assign the Toils by this Act granted, as Security for such Assessment so levied as aforesaid, with the legal Interest thereon, from the Tim» of its being levied till Payment; and the Persons paying such Assessment, on account of Lands contained in such Schedule, shall be entitled to charge on, and receive from the Tenants of such Lands on account of which such Assessment shall be levied, whose Leases shall bear Date prior to the passing of this Act, one Half of the Interest cf such Assessment, (in proportion to the real Rents paid by such Tenants,) during the Time that such Assessment shall not be repaid, or of such Part thereof as shall not be repaid; and all Persons being Proprietors of entailed Lands, included in such Schedule, shall be entitled to borrow such Sums so levied on the Credit and Security of the said entailed Lands; which Sums so borrowed shall continue a Burden on the said entailed Lands till repaid out of the Toll Duties hereby granted.

And be it enacted, That the said Trustees shall not be held or adjudged to have rendered themselves personally liable for the Repayment of the Money borrowed, or Interest thereof, by reason of having signed the Securities, which Securities are to be held and considered as granted upon the foie Credit and Security of the Tolls, unless specially expressed to the contrary 5 nor shall any Trustee or Subscriber be held personally liable, upon any Pretext for Payment of any Sum which he shall not have bound himself to pay personally, as an Individual, independant of his Office as a Trustee under this Act.

XXXIII. And be it enacted, That no Interest shall be paid on the Money subscribed, nor shall the principal Sums be demanded, till the Produce of the Tolls and Duties be in the Opinion of the Trustees, at a general Meeting assembled, sufficient to defray the Expence of Repairs, and other necessary Charges on the said Roads, to pay the Interest on the Debt thai may be incurred, and of the Sums subscribed; and that when it shall appear to the said Trustees, at a general Meeting assembled, that the Produce of the Tolls and Duties is sufficient for those Purposes, it shall and may be lawful for them to apply such Part of the Produce of the Tolls and Duties, as they shall judge expedient, in payment of the Sums subscribed, with Interest thereof, from the respective Periods at which these may have been advanced.

Provided always, and it is hereby enabled and declared, That if any Person or Persons within the said County, having Lands adjoining to any Part of the said Roads shall inclose such Lands on both Sides, he or they shall be obliged to leave fifteen Feet at least, free from the Middle of the Road to the Fence, and if one Side of any Part of the said Roads has been inclosed before passing this Act, and the other not inclosed, and it appear that the Proprietor of the Ground so inclosed has not left fifteen Feet free from the Middle of the Road to the Fences, the Heritor or PoffcfTor of such Ground on the other Side of the Road shall be obliged, at inclosing the fame, to leave the full Breadth of thirty Feec for the Breadth of the Road, and in case the Ground on the inclosed opposite Side does not belong to the Person lo inclosing, he or (be shall have Right to demand from the Proprietor of the Side first inclosed, or the said Trustees, a Sum equal to the Value of such Part of the said fifteen Feet, as hath not been leit out as aforesaid according as the Proprietor has or has not left the Road of the full Breadth to which he was bound by the Laws subsisting at the Time the inclosure was made; and in case of any Difference of Opinion thereon, ludi Value shall be determined by a Jury, to be appointed in Manner hereafter directed.

XLIV. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful fur the said Trustees to open Stone Quarries, and to dig, gather, take, and carry off Stones, Gravel, Furze, Heath, Sand, or other Materials from or out of any Waste Land or Common, or from any Brook or River running through Open Fields within the said County for the Purposes cf making or repairing the said Roads, or for building any Fences which the Tiuf-tees on the said Roads may be bound to build, without being subject to any Claim of Trespass, or Damage on that Account; and where there is no such Common, or where Sufficiency of Materials cannot be got Irom the fame within a reasonable Distance, it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, upon Intimation to the Proprietor or Possessor of such Grounds, at least Fourteen Days before working, to search, dig for, and gather such Materials in the Grounds of any Person or Persons where the same are or may be found, and from Time to Time to cause the same to be carried away, or so much thereof as the said Trustees shall judge necessary for the Purpose of making or repairing the said Roads, without Let or Hindrance from the Proprietor or PoiTeffor of the said Lands, paying always, within six Months thereafter, the Damage done to the Occupiers and Proprietors of the said Grounds from whence the same shall be so dug, gathered, and taken away, or over which the lame may be carried, as the lame shall be ascertained by any two or more Justices of the Peace of the said County; Provided that all Pits or Quarries in use for getting such Materials shall be fenced in and inclosed by the said Trustees: Provided always that it shall not be lawful to dig for Stone, Gravel, or other Materials, in any Ground where a House of the Value of Five hundred Pounds Hands, or in a Garden, Yard, Orchard, Planted Walk, Lawn around, or Avenue leading to such House, or in any Plantations or Woods necessary for the Ornament or Shelter of such House.

LVI. And be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for any two or more Justices of the Peace for the said County, upon Application of the Trustees, to suppress any Bye Roads, that do not appear to be of Importance to the Put'uc, so as to prevent any Person or Persons, travelling the Roads hereby directed to be repaired, from avoiding the Payment of any Tolls or Duties granted by this Act; Provided always, that Notice of the Resolution, to (hut up such Roads be given by Advertisements affixed to < he nearest: Turnpike Gate, and to the Doors of the three nearest Parish Churches for two consecutive Sundays, one Month at lead, before the Roads shall be actually (hut up, and that any Person or Persons, who shall think themselves injured by such Resolution, may apply to the Sheriff of the County, or his Substitute, who, if he fees Cause, is hereby empowered to suspend the Execution thereof, until the next General Quarter Sessions of the Peace for the said County; and the Determination of the Justices, at such Quarter Sessions shall be final and conclusive, without being subject to Review by Advocatiun, Suspension, or otherwise howsoever.

LVII. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees may cause Foot Paths, to the Breadth of eight Feet, to be made along the Sides of the said Roads, in such Places as can conveniently admit of the fame; and if any Person shall ride or drive a Carriage or Cattle upon any Foot Paths made or to be made, or shall in any way wantonly injure the fame, every such Person shall for every such Offence forfeit a Sum not exceeding Ten Shillings Sterling, to be levied in Manner herein after directed.

LVIII. And be it further enacted, That where the Ground on the Side of any of the said Roads is inclosed or planted, the Proprietors or Occupiers of such Ground shall be obliged, at the proper Sealon of the Year, to lop the Trees, Bushes, or Hedges in a proper Manner, so as to give sufficient Breadth and Air to the said Road, and in case they neglect to do so for six Months, after being required by an Order of the Trustees, the said Trustees shall have Power to appoint the same to be done at a proper Season of the Year, at the Defaulter’s Expence.

Guide Posts and Railings upon such Parts of the said Roads, where the Roads, are eroded or joined by other Roads as they shall judge proper.

And for preventing Annoyances in, or upon the said Roads, be it further enacted, That from and after two Months from the Commencement of this Act, every Person in ploughing any uninclosed Grounds or Fields contiguous to any of the said Roads, shall always make Head Ridges along the Sides of the said Roads, of the Breadth of eleven Feet at least j and every Person or Persons who shall not leave such Head Ridges, shall forfeit and pay any Sum, not exceeding ten Shillings Sterling; and all Gates upon Inclosures next to any of the said Roads, shall open inwards to the Field; and if any Person or Persons whatsoever shall lay or leave any dead Horses, (except in case of Accident,) or other Carrion, upon any of the said Road6, or within twenty Yards of the Sides of any of the said Roads, or any Dung, Lime, Soil, or Corrpost, or Matter whatsoever, either for manuring Land, or any other Purpose; or leave any Cart or Carriage without sufficient Cause, or the Loading thereof, or other Obstruction whatever, upon any of the said Roads, or within Five Yards of the Side thereof; or if any Person or Persons whatsoever shall leave any Horses, Oxen, Cows, Sheep, Lambs, Hogs, or other Cattle, on the said Roads, or any Part thereof, or suffer them to graze upon the Sides thereof, or on the Drains or Ditches along the fame, every such Person shall for every such Offence forfeit a Sum not exceeding ten Shillings Sterling.

And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall take off, or cause to be taken off, any Horse, Mare, or Gelding, or any Horses, Mares, or Geldings, from any Coach, Chaise, Chair, Chariot, Berlin, Landau, Calash, or Hearse, or any Horse or Horses, Ox or Oxen, or other Bead of Draught, from any Waggon, Wain, Cart, or other Carriage, before the same shall come to any of the Turnpike Gates, or Toll Bars, erected by virtue of this Act, with an Intent to avoid paying any Tolls or Duties hereby imposed, each and every Person or Persons so offending in any of the Cases aforesaid, and being thereof convicted, by the Oath of any one or more credible Witness or Witnesses, or his or their own Confession, before the Sheriff Depute or Substitute, or before any One or more of the Justices of the Peace, for the said County of Perth, or where the Offender shall reside, shall forfeit and pay a Sum not exceeding Five Pounds Sterling.

LXIV. And be it further enacted, That if any Person, occupying any Lands, or other Premises near to any of the said Roads, shall afljfl, or be accessary in permitting any Person to pass over the fame, or through any Gate or Passage with any Horse, Bead, or Carriage liable to pay Toll by virtue of this Act, or shall forcibly pass through, or alfifl any Person in passing through any Turnpike Gate or Toll Bar erected, or to be erected on the said Roads, whereby the Payment of such Toll may be evaded, such Person or Persons, so assisting or permitting, and the Person or Persons riding or driving such Horse, Bead, or Carriage, through such Grounds or private Passage, and any Person or Persons riding or driving any Horse, Beall, or Carriage through any private Road, whereby the Payment of the Toll may be avoided, or forcibly passing through any Turnpike Gate or Toll Bar, being convicted thereof, by the Testimony of one or more credible Witness or Witnesses, before the Sheriff Depute or Substitute, or any one or more of the Justices of the Peace for the said County of Perth, or where the Offender shall reside, shall, for every such Offence, forfeit and pay, to the said Trustees or their Treasurer, any Sum not exceeding five Pounds Sterling.

LXV. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons, having paid the Toll or Duty by this Act imposed, and having a Note or Ticket, Notes or Tickets signifying the Payment of such Toll or Duty, shall give, or dispose of the same to any other Person or Persons in order to avoid the Payment of the said Toll or Duty, every such Person, so giving or disposing of such Note or Ticket, Notes or Tickets, and the Person receiving the fame, being convicted thereof, upon the Oath of one or more credible Witness or Witnesses, or otherwise, before the Sheriff Depute or Substitute, or before any one or more of the Justices of the Peace for the said County, or where the Offender shall reside, shall for every such Offence, forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Twenty Shillings Sterling, to be levied and recovered in Manner hereinafter directed.

LXVIII. Cap. 21.

An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of several Acts passed in the Fifth, Sixth, and Twenty-sixth Years of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road from Tonbridge to Maidstone, and from Watts Cross to Cowden, in the County of Kent, so far as they relate to the Road from Tonbridge to Maidstone.

[25th July 1807.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign

of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repairing and 5G. 3. widening the Road from Tonbridge to Maidstone, and from Watts Cross to Cowden, in the County of Kent: And whereas an Act was passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His said present Majesty, intituled, An Act to explain and amend an Act made in the last Session of 6G.3. Parliament, for repairing and widening the Road front Tonbridge to Maidstone, and from Watts Cross to Cowden, in the County of Kent, so far as the fame relates to the Road from Tonbridge to Maidstone: And whereas an Act was passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of His said present Majesty, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Powers of Two Acts, paged in the Fifth 26 G. j. and Sixth Years of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening the Road c. 134., from Tonbridge to Maidstone, and from Warts Cross to Cowden, in the County of Kent, so far as the fame relate to the Road from Tonbridge to Maidstone: And whereas the Trustees appointed in or by virtue of the [Loc, (A Per.} 5 M said

said Acts, have proceeded to put the fame in Execution, for which Pur-p 'fe they have borrowed several considerable Sums of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted and continued, which Money Hill remains due and owing, and cannot be paid off; nor can the said Road be effectually amended, improved, and kept in Repair, tihlcfs the Term granted and continued by the said Acts is further continued, and feme of the Powers and Provisions thereof altered, amended, and enlarged; may it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the said recited Acts, passed respectively in the Fifth, Sixth, and Twenty-sixthYearsof the Reign of His said present Majesty King George the Third, and all and every the Powers, Authorities, Provisions, Regulations, Penalties, Forfeitures, Clauses, Matters, and Things therein respectively contained, (except such as relate to Exemptions from Stamp Duties), shall be and they are hereby further continued for and during the Term herein-after mentioned, as fully and effectually, to all Intents and Purposes, as if the fame were repeated and re-enacted in the Body of this Act; but subject nevertheless to the Amendments, Alterations, Variations, and Additions herein contained, and which shall commence and take effect immediately upon the passing of this Act; and this Acr, and the additional Term and Tolls hereby granted shall be, and they are hereby declared to be subject and fable to the Payment of all Sums of Money now due and owing on the Credit of the Tolls granted or authorized to be taken by the said recited Acts, and also of such other Sum and Sums of Money as shall or may be borrowed for the Purposes of the said Acts and this Act, and of all filtered due and to grow due for the fame respectively.

Cap. 24,

An Act for inclosing Lands in the Parish of Leng-hougbton, in the County of Nor t hum bar land.

[25th July 1807.]

WHEREAS there is within the Parish of Longbeugbton, in the County of Northumberland, a Common Moor or Tract of Waste Ground, called Longh ought on Common, containing by Estimation Five hundred and twenty Acres, or thereabouts: And whereas the Most Noble Hugh Duke of Northumberland is Lord of the Barony of Alnwick., and as such is seised of or entitled to the Soil and Inheritance, and the Mines, Minerals, Quarries, and Royalties, of, within, and und^r the said Common Moor or Waste: And whereas the said Hugh Duke of Northumberland is also Lord of the Manor and borough of Alemuth, in the said County of Northumberland: And whereas the said Hugh Duke of Northumberland, Edward Gallon of Alnwick, in the said County of Northumberland, Esquire, and several other Persons, are seized and possessed of divers Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments within the said Barony ot Alnwick and Manor and Borough of Alemouth, or one of them, and within the Parishes of Longhoughton and Lesbury, or one of them, and in respect thereof, or as appendant, appurtenant, or belonging thereto, they or their Lcffees, Farmers, or Tenants, are or claim to be entitled to Right of Common in and upon the said Common Moor or Waste: And whereas the said Common Moor or Waste, in its present State, is of little Use or Advantage, but is capable of Cultivation and Improvement; and the several Persons entitled to such Right of Common as atoreLid, are willing and desirous that the said Common Moor or Waste, with the Content of the said Lord of the said Barony and of the said Manor and Borough should [Lee. £sf Per.2 5 Z be

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That the Commissioners acting in the Execution of this Act, shall, at all and every of their Attendances or Meetings for putting this Act into Execution, bear and pay their own Expences; and that when and as soon as the said intended Division and other Purposes of this Act shall be finished and completed, and the said Commissioners shall have executed their said General Award, they the said Commissioners respectively shall be paid and allowed each of them the Sum of Three Pounds and Three Shillings for each and every Day upon which they respectively shall have attended a Meeting, and transacled Business in or for putting this Act into Execution.

XXXVI. An Act for inclosing Lands in the Manors and To;vn-ships of Hun ton, in the North Riding of the County of York.

[25th July 1807.]

WHEREAS, within the Manors and Township of Hunion, in the Parishes of Hornby and Patrick Brempton, in the North-Riding of the County of York, there is a Stinted Pasture called the Scrogp, and certain-open Fields called West Gill Field and Mill Gill, and several Parcels of Common and Wide Grounds, containing together, by Fflimation, One hundred and thirty' Acres, or thereabouts; and also a Tract of Common, or uninclosed Ground, called Hunton Moor or Common, containing also, by Estimation, Six hundred Acres, or thereabouts: And whereas Timothy Hutton, of Clifton Castle, in the said North-Riding, Ei'quire, is Lord of the said Manors of Hunton, and, as such, is seised of, and entitled unto, the Soil and Inheritance, and to the Mines, Minerals, (Quarries, and Royalties, within and under the said Waste Grounds and Moor or Common; and the said Timothy Hutton, together with Thomas Thornhill and Gregory F.l/lcy, Esquires; the Reverend John Theakstone Clerk; Thomas Other, John Hodgson, and John Anton, Gentlemen, and divers other Persons, are respectively Owners and Proprietors of a certain Number of Cattlegates and other Rights in the said open Fields, feme or one of them, and are also respectively Owners and Proprietors of ancient inclosed Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, within the said Manors, and in respect thereof, or at, appendant, appurtenant, or belonging thereto, they or their Trustees, [Lie. & Per.] ft E Lessees,

Cap. 26.

An Act for inclosing Chew Moor, in the Township of Lojlock, in the Parish of Bolton-in-the-Moors, in the County Palatine of Lancaster.

[25th July 1807.]

WHEREAS there is within the Township of Lojlock, in the Parish of Bolton-in-the-Moors, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, a certain Moor, Common, or Piece of Waste Ground, commonly called or known by the Name of Chew Moor, which contains Sixty-eight Acres One Rood and Thirty-six Perches, in Statute Measure, or theieabouts: And whereas Henry Blundell Esquire, Ralph Wright Gentleman, the Honourable Edward Perceval, and others, being Owners and Proprietors rei'ptctively of certain Messuages, Lands, and Tenements, within the said Township of Lojlock, in respect thereof, or otherwise, have severally for themselves and their respective Lessees and Tenants, pertain Estates, Rights, and Interests in, upon, and out of the said Moor: And whereas it would tend greatly to the Advantage of the several Persons having such Ertates, Rights, and Interests, in, upon, and out of the said Moor, Common, or Piece of Waste Ground, and render the Cultivation and Management thereof much more convenient, if the fame was divided and inclosed, and specific Parts thereof allotted to the several Perfor.s interested therein, in proportion to their respective Rights and Interests; but such Division, Allotment, and Inclosure, cannot be effected without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: And whereas an Act was passed in the Forty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for consolidating in One AR certain Provijitns usually infer ted in ARs of Inclosure, and for facilitating the Mode of proving the several FaRs usually required on the passing of such Alls: May it therefore pleaseYour Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent [Ick. isf Per.] 6 H " Majesty,

XXII. And be it further enacted, That all Orders and Proceedings of the said Commissioners at their respective Meetings shall be entered in a Book or Books to he provided for that Purpose, and that such Orders as shall be made by the said Commissioners shall be signed by them, which said Orders and Proceedings so entered in lucn Book or Books, and signed by the said Commissioners, shall and may be read in Evidence in all Suits, Actions, Jurisdictions, or other Proceedings in any Court whatever, concerning any Matter or Thing done or happening in relation to-, or in pursuance of this or the said recited Act.

XXIII. And be it further enacted, That out of the Money that shall be raffed or paid for defraying the Expences of obtaining and executing this and the said recited Act, there shall be paid to each of the said Commissioners, as a Recompence for his Pains and Trouble, the Sum of Two Pounds Twelve Shillings and Sixpence, and no more, for each Day he shall be employed in travelling, or engaged in the Execution of this or the said recited Act, and that each of the Lid Commissioners shall defray his travelling Expences, and also his own Expences, at all Meetings to be held in pursuance of this or the said recited Act; and that every Proprietor or other Person interested in the said Moor, Common, or Piece of Waste Ground, and also their Attornie* and Agents, shall at such Meetings pay and discharge his, her, and their own Expences.

XXIV. And be it further enacted, That once at lead in every Year during the Execution of this Act (such Year to be computed from the Day of the passing thereof) the said Commissioners shall and they are hereby required to make a true and just Statement or Account of all Sums of Money by them received and expended, or due to them for their own Trouble and Expences in the Execution of this Act; and such Statement or Account when so made, together with the Vouchers relating thereto, shall be by them laid before any One or more of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the said County of Lemcajltr, to be by him of them examined and balanced, and such Balance shall be by such Justice or Justices (fated in the Book or Books of Accounts to be kepr in the Office of the Clerk to the said Commissioners; and no Charge or Item in such Accounts shall be binding on the Parties concerned, or valid in Law, unless the same shall have been duly allowed by such Justice or Justices.

An Act for inclosingLands in the Parishes of Warlworth and Lesbury, in the County of Northumberland.

WHEREAS there is within the Parishes of Warkworth and Lef* bury, or one of them, in the County of Northumberland, a Common Moor or Tract of Wufte Ground, commonly called Threap Moor o'herwife Threap Ground, containing by Estimation, One hundred and Twenty Acres Three Roods and Twenty-eight Perches, or {hereabout: And whereas the most noble Hugh Duke of Northumberland is Lord of the Barony or Manor and Borough of Warkworth, and of the Barony of Alnwick, and as fu h is Owner of the Soil and Inheritance, and the Mines, Minerals, Quarries, and Royalties of, within and under the said Common Moor or Tratt of Wade Ground: And whereas the said Hugh Duke of Northumberland, Thomas Buston, of Buston in the County of Northumberland Esquire, and several other Persons are Lifed and possessed of divers MeffuSges, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments within the said Baronies, or Manors and Parishes, or some of them j and in respect thereof, or as appendant, appurtenant, or belonging thereto, they or their Lessees, Farmers, or Tenants, are entitled to Right of Common in and upon the said Common Moor or Waste Ground: And whereas confidmble Parts of the said Common Moor or Waite Ground are incapable of Cultivation and Improvement, and the fevrral Peri ins entitled to such Right of Common as aforesaid, are willing and drlirous that the said Common Moor or Waste, with the Consent of the said Lord of the said Bammes or Manors, should be divided and allotted by th>- Commiflii r.er or Commissioners in that Behalf, to be appointed [Lee. & Ber.J 6 L amongst

An Act for Inclosing Lands in the ParishC3 of Great St aught on and Graff ham, in the County of Huntingdon. [ 2 5 th July 1807.]

WHEREAS there are within the Parishes of Great Stoughton and Graffbam, in the County of Huntingdon, certain Common and Open Fields, Meadows, Commons, and other Commonable Lands and Grounds, containing Two Thousand Acres, or thereabouts, of which One hundred and thirteen Acres, or thereabouts, are situate in that Part of the Hamlet of Perry, which is called East Perry, and which is within the said Parish of Graffbam; and all the Residue thereof are situate within the said Parish of Great Staughton: And whereas the Most Noble William Duke of Manchester, Sir James Duberly Knight, Arthur Walter Esquire, the Reverend Frogmere Cummhtg Clerk, as Vicar of the United Vicarages of Cardington and Keyfoe, the Reverend Harry Wel/lead Clerk, the Reverend Hugh Wade Gery Clerk, and also the fame Hugh Wade Gery, John Milnes Esquire, and the Reverend Thomas Milnes Clerk, as his Co-proprietors, are respectively Owners of several Parts of the Impropriate ReGory of Great Staughton, and are entituled to certain Tythes arising within the said Parish of Great Staughton: And whereas the President and Scholars of Saint John the Baptist’s College, Oxford, are Patrons of the Vicarge of Great Staughton aforesaid, and the Reverend James Pope Clerk is Vicar thereof, and entitled to certain Tythes, or Compositions in lieu thereof, arising within the said Parish of Great Staughton: And whereas Lady Olivia Bernard Sparrow is Patroness of the Rectory of Graffbam aforesaid and the Reverend Samuel Parr DoGor of Laws, is ReGor thereof, and entitled to the Great and Small Tythes arising within the said Parish of Graffbam; And whereas the Lac. lit Per 7} 6 Q King’s

XXXIV. And be it further enacted, That when, and so soon as any of the publick Carriage Roads to be set out in pursuance of the said Act, and this Act, shall be completed, and put into good and fulEcient Repair, it shall be lawful for the Justices of the Peace of and for the said County of Huntingdon, at any special Sessions or Meeting to be holden for the Purpose, to declare such Road or Roads to be fully and sufficiently formed, completed, and repaired; from which Time, and for ever thereafter, such Road or Roads shall be supported and kept in repair by such Persons, and in like Manner as the publick Roads now are, or ought, by Law, to be amended and kept in Repair.

Cap. 29.

An Act for amending, rendering more effectual, and continuing Parts of an Act of the Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Year of His present Majesty, for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgow over certain adjacent Lands, for paving, lighting, and cleaning the Streets, and other Purposes in the said Act mentioned. [ 1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS an Act passed in the Thirty-ninth and Fortieth

Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act £5t0,',&4° for extending the Royalty of the City of Glasgow over certain e°’3* adjacent Lands; for paving lighting, and cleansing the Streets \ for regulating the Police, and appointing Officers and Watchmen; for dividing the City into Wards, and appointing Commissioners; and for raising Funds and g ving certain Powers to the Magistrates and Council and Town and Dean of Guild Courts, for the above and other Purpf-s: And whereas the Provisions 01 the said Act, which have been carried into Execution, have produced the most beneficial Consequences to the said City and Inhabitants thereof, parti u-larly those Parts which relate to the Division of the said City into Districts or Wards, the Appointment of Commissioners for the said Wards, and of Officers, Clerks, Collectors, and Watchmen, and the laying on and levying of the Affefltnrnt therein directed. and hereinafter specified, which Parrs of she said Act are now near expiring: And whereas, it is of great Importance, and will promote the Security, Comfort, and Convenience of the Inhabitants of the said City, that those Parts of the said Act above reefed, which are not perpetual, should be continued, and the fame, and other Parts [Lee. id Per.] 6 2 thereof

Judges, and Magistrates, with their Officers, Messengers at Arms, and all other Officers and Executors of the Law whomsoever, are he. eby required to be aiding and assisting in putting this Act into due and lawful Lxccu-tion; and that this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by ail Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

I.XX. And be it enacted, That the several Parts of this Act which relate to the laying on and levying the Assessment herein-before directed, appointing Officers, Clerks, Collectors, and Watchmen, dividing the City into Distrists or Wards, and appointing Commissioners of the said Wards, shall continue in force for Fourteen Years from and after the passing thereof, and to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, and no-longer; but that all the other Parts of this Act shall be perpetual.

LONDON: Printed by George Eyre and Andrew Strahan, Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty. 1807.

V. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the Directors of the said Company, or any Five or more of them, who shall direct and superintend the Erection and Building of the said intended Wall, to substitute a strong and substantial Iron Railing in the Place of the upper Part of the said Wall, when such Wall shall be raised Eight Feet from the Surface of the Ground at lead, such Iron Railing being of such a Height that the said Wall and the Iron Railing together shall be Twelve Feet in Height at the least above the Ground any Thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

VI. And be it further enacted, That the Surplus Rates and Duties granted or made payable to the said West India Dock Company by the said recited Acts, made in the Thirty-ninth and Forty-second Years of His present Majesty's Reign, after Payment of all the Demands to which the same are now made subject, shall be and are hereby declared to be charged with the Re-payment to the said Consolidated Fund of the Monies to be advanced thereout to the said West India Dock Company, in pursuance of this Act, with Interest for the lame, at the Rate of Five

Pounds

47° GEORGII III. Sess. 2. Cap. 31.

Pounds per Centum per Jnnum from the Time or respective Times of advancing and paying the fame until Re-payment thereof, and that after full Payment and Satisfaction, all the Charges, Expences, Outgoings, Dividends, and Interest, to which the Rates and Duties granted to the said Company are subject and liable, the Residueor Surplus of the Monies to arise and be received therefrom shall be applied from Time to Time in repaying and replacing to the said Consolidated Fund all such Sum and Sums of Money as shall be advanced and paid thereout to the said West India Dock Company, or their Treasurer for the Time being, in pursuance of this Act, with Interest for the fame, at the Rate aforesaid; and when all the Monies which shall be advanced and paid to the said Company out of the said Consolidated Fund shall be fully repaid, with Interest as aforesaid, then and from thenceforth the said Rates and Duties so as aforesaid granted or made payable to the said Company, shall and may be lowered in the Manner and subject to the Conditions and Provisions in and by the said recited Act, made in the Thirty-ninth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, directed.

VII. And be it further enacted, That the said West India Dock Company shall, from Time to Time, by and out of the Rates granted to them by the said recited Acts, made in the Thirty-ninth and Forty-second Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, keep the said intended Wall, Offices, and Barracks, hereby authorized and directed to be erected and built, in good and substantial Repair.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons of the City of London, in Common Council assembled, shall pay and discharge one Moiety of all the Costs and Charges incident to and incurred in obtaining and passing this Act, with and out of any Monies paid or to be paid into the Chamber of the City of London from and out of the said Consolidated Fund, in pursuance of the several hereinbefore recited Acts, and of this Act, or of any of them as aforesaid, and the other Moiety thereof shall be paid by the said West India Dock Company, out of the Monies to be advanced to them from and out of the Consolidated Fund as hereinbefore mentioned.

IX. And be it further enacted, That all such or so much of the Powers, Authorities, Provisions, Regulations, Directions, Clauses, Matters, and Things whatsoever, contained in the said recited Act of the Thirty-ninth Year of His present Majesty's Reign as are applicable to the Purposes of this Act, and not hereby repealed, altered, or otherwise provided for or rendered unnecessary, shall extend and be construed to extend to this present Act, and shall operate and be in force in respect to this Act and the Purposes thereof, according to its true Meaning, as fully and effectually to all Intents and Purposes as if the fame Powers, Authorities, Provisions, Regulations, Directions, Clauses, Matters, and Things were particularly repeated andre-enacted in the Body of this Act.

Cap. 32.

An Act to enable His Majesty to grant the Citadel and Walls of the City of Carlisle, and certain Grounds adjoining thereto, to the Justices of the Peace for the County of Cumberland, for building Courts of Justi ce for the said County, and for other Purposes relating thereto. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS there is no Shire Hall, or other public, convenient, \ \ f or proper Building, for holding the Assizes and Quarter Sessions V f for the County of Cumberland, nor any Place for depositing the Public Records of the said County, and the Assizes for the said County have, from Time immemorial, been holden by Permission of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council of the City of Carlisle, in the Guildhall of the said City, which is so incommodious and in such a ruinous State as to be extremely inconvenient for the Administration of Justice, and even unsafe and dangerous to His Majesty's Judges of Assize, and all His Majesty's liege Subjects attending on such Occasions, and the said Judges of Assize have repeatedly so represented the fame in their Charges to the Grand Juries for the said County: And whereas the Justices of the Peace for the said County, having taken the Premises into their Consideration, employed a proper Engineer and Architect to point out and select the mod eligible Place or Scite for erecting sufficient Courts of Justice, and other proper Offices, who stated to them, and they have themselves examined the fame, and are of opinion, that the only fit and proper Place, [Loc. IsfPer.] 7 H within

582 47° GEORGII IIEI Cap$i.

within or adjoining the said- City of Carlisle, for such Purposes, will be the: Citadel and Two Bastions, on the South Entrance to the said City of Carli/Ie, (which adjoin the (Common Gaol of the said County), together with Inch Parts of the Walls of the said City as adjoin thereto, and the Sdites of such Bastions and Walls, and the Ground adjoining thereto, extending in length from the South West End of the Western Bast;on One hundred and forty Yards, and from the South East Bastion in a North Eastern Direction Twenty-four Yards: And whereas the King’s most Excellent Majesty, in right of His Crown, is seised in Fee Simple of the said Citadel, and Bastions and Walls, and of the Scites thereof, and of the Ground adjoining to Parts thereof: And whereas the said Citadel and Bastions, Wails and Scites, together with the Stones of the old Walls surrounding the said City, are of small Value, and not of any public Utility, yet the fame would be of very great Use and Benefit to the said County for the Purposes aforesaid: And whereas, upon the humble Application of the Justices of the Peace acting in and for the said County of Cumberland, His Majesty has been graciouflypleased to signif, IlisRoyaiWill and Pleasure, thatfo far as His Majesty’sInterest is concerned, the said Citadtl and Two Bastions, with the Walls aforesaid, together with the Scites there-: of, and the Ground adjoining thereto, and also the Stones of the old Walls surrounding the said Gity, should be absolutely veiled in His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the Time being, acting in and for the County of Cmnberland, for the Purpose of erecting a sufficient and proper Shire Haft, Court House or Court Houses, and other Offices for holding the Assizes, and for such other public Uses and Purposes as the said Justices of the Peace for the said County of Cumberland for the Time being, or the major Part of them, at the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace, shall from Time to Time order, direct, and appoint: And whereas it is expedient that the Justices of the Peace for the said County should be empowered to defray the Expences of building, erecting, and fumishing such Court Houses and other Offices, and for purchasing any other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments as may be necessary for such Purposes, by and out of the County Stock or Rates; but as such Purposes cannot be effected without the Aid and Authority of Parliament, may it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enabled by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, Veiling the and by the Authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this Cuadel, the said Citadel, Bastions, and Walls surrounding the said City, and

Wall°nVnthe she Scites thereof respectively, and the Ground adjacent thereto, so far as justices for His Majesty's Interests are concerned therein, shall be, and the fame is the County, and are hereby granted and confirmed unto, and shall be veiled for ever in His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the Time being, acting in and for the said County of Cumberland, freed and absolutely discharged from' all Claim, Right, and Title of His Majesty, in right ot His Crown, His Heirs and Successors.

XXV. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That no Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall recover in any Action to be commenced against any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this Act, unless Notice in Writing shall have been given to the Defendant or Defendants, or left at his or their last or usual Place or Places of Abode Ten Days before such Action shall be commenced, of such intended Action, signed by the Attorney for the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, specifying the Cause of such Action; nor shall the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs recover in such Action if Tender of sufficient Amends shall have been made to him, her, or them, or to his, her, or their Attorney, by or on Behalf of the Defendant or Defendants before such Action brought; and in case no such Tender shall have been made, it shall and may be lawful to and for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action, by leave of the Court where such Action shall depend, at any Time before Issue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he, she, or they shall think fit, whereupon such Proceedings, Order, and Judgement shall be had, made, and given in and by such Court, as in other Actions where the Defendant is allowed to pay Money into Court.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO SEPTIMO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

An Act for ascertaining and establishing the Rates of Wharfage, Cannage, Plankage, Anchorage, and Moorage, to be received at the lawful Quays in the Port of Bristol; for the Regulation of the Cranekeepers in the said Port; and for the better Regulation of Pilots and Pilotage of Vessels navigating tht Bristol Channel. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS the Mayor, Burgesses, and Commonalty of the City of Bristol, by antient Charters and Grants from the Crown, have been for several Hundred Years pad Owners of the Port of Bristol, with several Creeks and Harbours in the Bristol Channel as Members thereof; and the said Corporation are Conservators of the Rivers within the said Port from a certain Place about Four Miles East-ward of the said City to Kingroad and so down the River Severn and Bristol Channel, to the Two small Islands called The Stipe Holmes and The Flat Holmes, and are seised of and in all and Angular the Wharfs and Quays used as lawful Quays in the City and Port of Bristol; and they.the said Mayor, Burgesses, and Commonalty, or their Lessees, have from Time to Time erected, made, and laid out, for the Use and Accommoda-

XVII. And whereas by an Act, passed in the Forty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for improving and rendering more commodious the Port and Harbour of Bristol, Authority is given to the Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Councilmen, in Common Council assembled, from Time to Time, to fix and ascertain the Rates to be taken by’ Pilots within the said Port of Bristol, which extends to the said Blands called The Flat Holmes and Stipe Holmes: And whereas it is expedient that such Authority be extended over the Whole of the Bristol Channel; be it therefore further enacted, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Councilmen of the’ said City, in Common Council assembled, and they are hereby authorized and required to establish regular Rates of Pilotage for all Pilots licensed for the said Bristol Channel, and also Rates or Allowances for Pilots taken to Sea; and it shall be lawful for the said Justices in General Quarter' Sessions assembled, from Time to Time to alter or vary, increase or diminish such Rates, giving Notice of such Rates, and of all Alterations therein, by hanging up Tables thereof at the Custom House in the said Port of Bristol.

XXX. And be it further enacted, That all Fines and Penalties to be levied in pursuance of this Act, unless otherwise specially appropriated, shall go to and be received by the Chamberlain of the City of Bristol for the Time being, and be applied from Time to Time in the Relief of super-annuated or decayed Pilots, who shall have acted under Licences granted by this Act, in such Manner as the Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council of the said City in Common Council assembled, shall from Time to Time appoint and direct.

XXXI. And be it further enacted, That in case any Person against whom a Warrant shall be ifltied by any Justice or justices before or after any Conviction for any Offence against this Act shall escape, go into a Residence, or be in any County, Riding, Division, City, Liberty, Town, or Place out of the Jurisdiction of such Justice or Justices granting such Warrant or Warrants, or if the Goods and Chattels of any Offender convicted of any Offence in pursuance of this Act shall be in a different County, Riding, Division, City, Liberty, Town, or Place, than where the said Party was convict ft, or Warrant of I) ill refs granted, it shall be lawful for any Juf-tia or the i eace of the County, Riding, Division, City, Liberty, Town, or P;a.-e, into which the Party shall escape cither before or after Conviction, and they and every of them are hereby required, upon Proof made upon O th of the Hand Writing of any Justice or Justices granting such Warrant or Warrants, to indorse his or their Name or Names, on such Warrant, and the fame, when so indorsed, shall be a sufficient Authority to all Peace Officers to execute such Warrant in such County, Riding, Division, Ciry, Town, or Place out of the Jurisdiction of the Justice or Justices respectively on the Offender or Offenders being apprehended and brought before him or them within their respective Jurisdictiogs, may proceed to hear and determine the Complaint, and may direct the Offender or Offenderkto be carried to the Justices or Justice who granted the original Wart-ant to be dealt with according to Law,

XXXII. And be it further enacted, That where any Distress shall be r ide for any Sum or: Sums of Money to be levied by virtue of this Act, the Distress itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor shall the Party or Parties malting the fame be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers on account of any Defect or Want of Form in the Summons, Conviction, Warrant of Dif-jrtf1, or the Proceedings relating thereto, nor shall the Party or Parties be deemed a V--efpasser or I 'respassers ab initio, on account of any Irregularity Which shall be afterwards committed by the Party or Parties distrainintr, but- the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity ft all and may recover full Satisfaction for the special Damage sustained in an Action on the Cafe.

XXXIII. And, for the more easy and speedy Conviction of Offenders Conriffion of again (I this Act; be it further enacted, That all and every Justice and Justices of the Peace before whom any Person shall be convicted of any Offence again(f this Act, shall and may in all Cases where the Form of Conviction is not herein-before directed, cause the Conviction to be drawn up according to the following Form; videlicet,

T? E it remembered, That on the Day of

‘ in the Year of our Lord

A.B. is convicted before me [or, us] One [or. Two,

as the Case may be] of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the

« [here specify the County, City, Divijim,

or Place, or City, Town, or Part where the Conviction shall be, and also the Offence, and the Time and Place when and where committed, as the Case may be] contrary to an Act, passed in the Forty-seventh Year of the Reign of King George the Third, intituled, [here insert the Title

of this Act] for which Offence I adjudge the said A.B. to have forfeited

the Sum of Given under my Hand

and Seal [or, our Hands and Seals] the Day and Year first beiore-‘ mentioned.’

XXXIV. And it is hereby enacted, That no Certiorari, or other Writ or Process for the Removal of any such Conviction or any Proceedings thereon, into any of His Majesty's Courts of Record at Westminster, shall be allowed or granted.

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to Appeal, and for any Person or Persons so convicted by any Justice or Justices of the Peace as before-mentioned, of any Offence or Offences against this Act, or against any Rule, Order, or Bye Law made in pursuance thereof, within Three Calendar Months next after such Conviction, to appeal to the Justices of the Peace assembled at the General Quarter Sessions or General Sections holden for the County, City, or Place where the Order or Conviction so appealed against shall have been made, first giving Ten Days Notice of such Appeal, to the Person or Persons appealed against, and of the Matter thereof, and within Fourteen Days next after such Notice entering into a Recognizance before some Justice of the Peace of such County, City, or Place, with sufficient Sureties conditioned to try such Appeal, and for abiding the Determination of the Court therein , and such Justices shall, upon Proof of such Notice having been given and Recognizance entered into, hear and determine the Matter of such Appeal, and may either confirm or quash, and annul the said Conviction, and award such Costs to either Party as to them shall seem just and reasonable; and the Decision of the said Justices therein shall be final, binding, and conclusive, and no Proceedings to be had or taken in pursuance of this Act shall be quashed or vacated for Want of Form only, or be removed by Certiorari, or any Writ or Process whatsoever into any of His Majesty's Courts at Westminster or elsewhere, any Law or Statute to the contrary notwithstanaing.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted, That if any Suit or Action shall be Limitation brought or prosecuted against any Person or Persons for any Thin"- done of Actiom.

or to be done in pursuance or by colour of this Act, in every such Case the Action or Suit shall be commenced within Six Calendar Months next after the Fact committed and not afterwards, and shall be laid or brought in the County, City, or Place where the Cause of Action arises, and not elsewhere; and the Defendant or Defendants in such Action or Suit may plead the General I flue, and give the Special Matter in Evidence upon any Trial to be thereupon had, and that the fame was done under or by virtue of this Act; and if it shall appear so to be done, or if any such Action or Suit shall be brought after the Time limited for bringing the same, then the Jury shall find for the Defendant or Defendants; or if the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall become noni'uited, or suffer a Discontinuance of his, her, or their Action or Actions, or if a Verdict shall pass against the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, the Defendant or Defendants shall have Treble Costs, and shall have such Remedies for the same as any Defendant or Defendants hath or have for Colts of Suits in other Cases of Law.

Publick Act.

XXXVII. And it is hereby further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Sess. 2.

Cap. 34-

An Act for empowering the Justices of the Peace for the County of Kent to make a fair and equal County-Rate for the said County; and provide convenient Court Houses for holding the Assizes and General Quarter Sessions of the Peace and other public Meetings within the said County.

[ 1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS an Act was made in the Forty-third Year of the \/\/ His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repealing <3g-j- c-i*

V T so much of an API, made in the Ninth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, intituled, ‘An Act to enable the justices of the Peace,

‘ acting for the Western Div'fion of the County of Kent, to purchase a convenient Piece of Ground for building a Gaol for the said County, and for 1 empowering the said Justices to apply Part of the County Stock of the said

Divi/ion towards the same, as requires that the said Gaol should be repaired

exclusively at the Expence of the said Western Division, and for the better ‘ Regulation and Payment of the publick Expences of the said County :*

And whereas it is expedient that Power and Authority should be given to the Justices of the Peace for the said County of Kent in their General or Quarter Sessions assembled, to make a fair and equal County Rate, and for that Purpose to assess and tax rateably and in due Proportions all and every the Parishes, Towns, Liberties, Precincts, Villages, Hamlets, and Places within the said County, according to the annual Rent or Value of Estates therein, for and towards the fame: And whereas the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace for the said County of Kent are holden at Maid-

X. And be it further enacted and declared, That all and-every the Clauses, Powers, Directions, Provisions, and Authorities contained in the said recited Acts made in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, and in the Forty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, and so much of an Act made in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of King Georg: the Second, intituled, An Act to continueftveral Laws therein mentioned for punishing fttcb Persons as shall iwilfully and malt clou fly full down or destroy Turnpikes; for repairing Highways or Locks, or other Wcrks ercCled by Authority of Parliament; for snaking Rivers navigable; for presenting Exactions of the Occupiers of Locks and Wears upon the River of Thames IVeflward, and for ascertaining the Rates of Water Carriage upon the said River-, for preventing frivolous and vexatious Arrefs, and for the better securing the lawful Trade of His Majesty's Subjects to and from the Fall Indies, and for the more effectual preventing all His Majesty's Subjects trading thither under Foreign Commissions, and for limiting the Time forfuing forth IVrits of Certiorari upon Proceedings before Justices of the Peace, and for regulating the Time and Manner of applying for the fame; for the better and more speedy Execution of Proctfs within particular Franchises or Liberties, and for extending the Powers and Authorities of Justicei of the Peace of Counties touching County Rates, to the j'ufliccs of the Peace of such Liberties and Franchises as have Commissions of the Peace within thenselves, as relates to County Rates, (save and except such Parts thereof as are hereby varied, altered, or repealed), and shall be good, valid, and effectual for carrying this Act into Execution.

XI. Provided always, and be it enacted, That all the Colts, Charges, and Expences of obtaining this Act, and of carrying the several Powers and Purposes thereof into Execution, shall be borne and paid by the said County, in such Proportions as the Charges, Burthens, and Expences arising within the County, to which a County Rate is or may be applicable, are, by the said recited Act made in the Forty-third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, directed to be paid; (that is to say), One-Fourth Part thereof shall be borne and paid by the Eastern Division of the said County, and the other Three-Fourth Parts thereof shall be borne and paid by the Western Division of the said County.

An Act to enable the Reverend Alban Thomas Jones Gwynne, his Heirs and Assigns, to repair and enlarge or rebuild the Quay or Pier within the Harbour or Port of Aberayron, in the County of Cardigan; and to improve the said Harbour, and to regulate the Moorings of Ships and Vessels

WHEREAS the Quay or Pier within the Harbour or Port of %/» / Aberayron, in the P2ri(h of Henfcniew, and in the Manor of ▼ v Llyfwen otherwise Aberayron, in the County of Cardigan, is become ruinous and insufficient for the Accommodation and Protection of the Ships and Vessels retorting to the said Harbour: And whereas Alban Thomas Jones Gwynne Clerk, Lord of the said Manor of Llyfwen otherwise Aberayron, is willing and desirous, at his own Expence, to rebuild, enlarge, improve, and maintain the said Quay or Pier, and also to improve the said Harbour: And whereas the Rates or customary Dues payable by the Owners and Matters of Ships and other Vessels making use of the said Harbour, have been found inadequate to support and maintain the fame, and are not properly ascertained, and there are not sufficient Powers to enforce the Payment thereof, and it is necessary, in order to the putting of the said Quay or Pier in proper Repair, and to the keeping of the fame and the said Harbour in good Order and Condi-

Cap. 56.

An Act to enable His Majesty to vest the Sands of Traeth Mawr, dividing the Counties of Carnarvon and Merioneth, in William Alexander Madocks Esquire. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS there is a certain Trail of Sands situate on the Estuary called Traeth-Mawr, dividing the Counties of Carnarvon and Merioneth, and extending from Pont Aberglaflyn to the Point of Gift, which, in its present State, is unproductive and incapable of being cultivated, and the Passage over the fame is frequently attended with great Inconvenience, Delay, Difficulty, Expence, and Danger: And whereas, if the said Sands were proteCled from the Sea by Embankments and other necessary Works, the fame might be cultivated and rendered productive, and the Communication between the said Two Counties would be thereby greatly facilitated and improved, and such Embankments and Works would also be ofpublick Utility, but the making and maintaining of the fame will be attended with considerable Difficulty and Expence: And whereas William Alexander Madocks, of Tan yr Allt, in the County of Carnarvon, Esquire, is deftrous of constructing and making such Embankments, Sea Walls, Ramparts, Fences, Sluices, Bridges, and other Works, as may be necessary for protecting the said Sands from the Influx of the Sea, at his own Expence, on having the fame vested in him and his Heirs and Assigns in Fee Simple: And whereas His Majesty, in right of His Crown, claims to be entitled to the said Sands, and being deftrous of encouraging Undertakings of publick Utility, His Majesty has been mod graciously pleased to signify his royal Pleasure, that so much of the said TraCl of Sands from the Point of Gift to Pont Aberglaflyn aforesaid, as shall be protected from the Influx of the Sea, by the said William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs or Assigns, in Manner aforesaid, shall (as far as His Majesty is interested therein! be [Z.w. Is Per.\ i E granted

For enabling His Majesty to veil certain Sands in William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs, &c.

granted and and confirmed to, and vested in the said William Alexander Madocis, his Heirs and Assigns, in Fee Simple; bur, as Inch His Majesty's Pleasure cannot fee carried into Effect without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That so much of the said Sands as shall in Manner aforesaid be protected from the influx of the Sea by the said William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs or Assigns, shall be, and the same are hereby vested in and confirmed unto the said William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs and Assigns, freed and absolutely discharged from all Claim, Right, and Title whatsoever of His Majesty, in right,of Llis Crown and Dignity, and of His Heirs and Successors: Provided nevertheless, that nothing in this Act contained shall be confirmed or taken to vest in the said William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs or Assigns, any of the Marsh Lands adjoining the said Sands, and which have hitherto been occupied or enjoyed as Pasturage, and as Parc of, or as appurtenant to any Freehold Lands or Tenements.

II. And be it further enacted, That Benjamin Wyatt of Lime Grove, in the County of Carnarvon, Esquire, shall be, and he is hereby appointed a Commissioner for ascertaining, letting our, and determining the Boundaries of the said Tract of Sands by virtue of this Act, to be granted to the said William Alexander Madocks, his Heirs and Assigns, and of the Marsh Lands hereby made liable to the Payment of an Annual Rene as herein-after mentioned.

Cap. 37.

An Act to explain, amend, and render more effectual several Acts for improving the Navigation of the River Loyne, otherwise Lune; and for building a Quay or Wharf near Lancaster, in the County Palatine of Lancaster. £1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, An Act for improving the Navigation of the River Loyne, otherwise called Lune; and for building a Quay or Wharf near the Town of Lancaster, in the County Palatine of Lancaster; And whereas another Act was passed in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act to explain and amend'an Ail made in the Twenty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Second, for improving the Navigation of the River Loyne, otherwise called Lune, and for building a Quay or Wharf near the Town of Lancaster, in the County Palatine of Lancaster: And whereas another Act was parted

XIV. Provided also, and be it enacted, That where by reason of any Disability or Incapacity of the Person or Persons, or Corporation entitled to any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be purchased under the Authority of the said recited Acts and this Act, the Purchase Money for the same shall be required to be paid into the Court of Chancery, and to be applied in the Purchase of other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, to be settled to the like Uses, in pursuance of the Paid recited Acts and this Act, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court of Chancery to order the Expences of all Purchases from Time to Time to be made in pursuance of the said recited Acts and this Act, or so much of such Expences as the said Court shall deem reasonable, to be paid by the said Commissioners and Trustees out of the Monies to be received by virtue of the said recited Acts and this Act, who shall, from Time to Time, pay such Sums of Money for such Purposes as the said Court shall direct.

XV. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioners and Trustees shall, and they are hereby empowered, by Writing, to be signed by any Five or more of them, to grant Licences to such a Number of proper Persons to conduct or pilot Ships or Vessels into or out of the said River and Port, and fix and order such Rates for the fame; and shall have Power from Time to Time to discharge any such Pilot so licensed, and to alter such Rates, and do all other Matters which the said Commissioners and Trustees, or any Five or more of them, shall judge proper in that Behalf, a Copy of all which Licences shall be entered in a Boole* to be provided and kept for that Purpose by the Clerk to the said Corn, missioners and Trustees j and if any Person or Persons shall take upon him or themselves to conduct or pilot any Ship or Vessel into or out of the said River and Port, without being licensed so to do as herein-before directed, every such Person so offending shall, for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceedingTen Pounds: Provided nevertheless, that nothing herein contained shall extend to prevent any Persons from assisting Vessels in Distress, or from piloting the fame when licensed Pilots cannot be obtained: Provided always, that it shall and may be lawful to and for tr,e said Commissioners and Trustees, or any Five or more of them, from Time to Time to make, constitute, and ordain all such reasonable Bye Laws, Rules, and Regulations for the good Rule and Government of the said Pilots as to them in their DilCrction shall feern n\eet, and also from Time to Time to repeal, vary, alter, or amend 'any such Bye-Laws, Rules, and Regulations, such Bye-Laws, Rules, and Regulations not to be repugnant to any Thing in this Act contained, or contrary to any Law or Statute of that Part of the United Kingdom called England, and also ascertain and let down what pecuniary Penalties or Forfeitures shall be incurred by any Person breaking or evading the lame, so that no Penalty or Forfeiture exceed the Sum off ive Pounds for any one Offence; which Penalties may be levied and recovered in Manner directed by the said recited Acts: Provided also, that a Copy of the said Bye-Laws, Rules, and Regulations shall be printed, and be and remain affixed or hung up in fomc conspicuous Parc of the Custom-house at Lancaster, and of the Office for Receipt of the Rates and Duties hereby granted; XVI. And be it further enacted, That in case any Master or Commander of any Ship or Vessel, which shall at any Time hereafter be bound or going into or out of the said Port of Lancaster, (except Vessels in Ballad, or Coaders,) shall refuse to take on board, or employ a Pilot licensed as aforesaid, who shall offer his Services, and produce his Licence, such Mader, Commander, or the Owner, Agent, Consignee, or Broker, acting for such Vessel, shall pay, or caute to be paid to the Pilot, who shall first offer his Services, and be so refused, the full Pilotage, according to the said respective Rates, as if the said Pilot had been employed to conduct, and had conduced such Ship or Vessel into or out of the said Port or River} and the like Powers and Authorities are hereby granted to such Pilots, who shall be so licensed as aforesaid, for the Recovery of any Rates due to them, as are vested in the Commissoners and Trustees for the Recovery of any Duties or Tonnage granted by this or the former Acts.

XVII. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissoners and Trustees shall have Power to demand and receive from each Pilot any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings for his Licence, which Sum, together with the Monies arising from Fines to be inflicted upon Pilots as aforesaid, shall, after defraying the Expences of managing the Affairs of the said Pilots, be applied, under the Direction of the said Commissoners and Trustees, to the Relief of Poor or disabled Pilots, belonging to the said Port and River, their Widows and Children.

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That the Charges and Expences of obtaining and paffng this Act shall be defrayed out of the Rates and Duties granted by the said recited Acts and this Act.

XIX. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such, by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

SCHEDULE

47° GEORGII III. Sess.2. Cap 37.

SCHEDULE to which this Act refers.

For every Ship or Vessel coming into or going out of the said Port of Lancaster, or trading to or from any Port or Place in Europe, within the Streights, or Mediterranean Sea, or to or from any Port or Place in Afr:;a, America, or Greenland, the Sum of Three Shillings for every Ton of the Burthen or Tonnage ofevery such Shipor Vessel respectively:

For every Ship or Vessel coming into or going out of the said Port, and trading to or from any Foreign Part or Place in Europe, (except Ireland, ti e Ifie of Man, and the Streights or Mediterranean Sea,) the Sum of Two Shillings for every Ton of the Burthen or Tonnage of every furh Ship or Vessel respectively:

For every Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter coming into or going out of the said Port, and trading to or from any Port or Place in Great Britain, situate South of Holyhead, and North of the Mull of Galloway, the Sum of One Shilling nd Sixpence forevtry Ton of the Burthen or Tonnage of every such Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter respectively: For tvery Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter coming into, or going out of the said Port, and trading to or from any Port or Place, in Ireland or the Ifie of-Man, the Sum of One Shilling for every Ton of the Burthen or Tonnage of every such Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter respectively:

For every Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter, coming into or going out of the said Port, and trading to or from any Port or Place in Great Britain, North of Holyhead, and South of the Mull of Galloway, the Sum of Sixpence for every Ton of the Burthen or Tonnage of every such Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter respectively:

And for every Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter, coming in Ballad into the said River Loyne, and not lading or unlading within the said Port, for every Ton, One-fourth Part of the said several Rates and Duties charged and imposed on any Ship, Vessel, Bark, or Lighter of the fame Burthen or Tonnage respectively by this Act.

LXV. And whereas the Commissioners under and by virtue of the said Annuitie* Two former Acts did, in pursuance of the Powers and Authorities of the granted unfame Acts, grant unto divers Persons certain Annuities or Yearly Sums of Money, upon the Credit of, payable out of, and charged upon the Rates chargfSbIeoB and Assessinfients made, raised, and collected by virtue of the said Two fta;es?ob« several Acts, many of which Annuities are now payable and outstanding; by be it further enacted, That all and every the Rate and Rates, Assessmenc and Assessments, to be made, laid, assessed, and collected in pursuance of this Act, shall from Time to Time and at all Times hereafter be and continue subject and liable to and charged with all and each and every the Annuity and Annuities, and other Charges and Incumbrances granted, made, or charged in pursuance of the said former Acts or eicher of them, upon the Rates or Alik ffments thereby authorized or directed to be made, laid, or assessed; and all and every such Annuity or Annuities shall be paid and payable out of the Monies arising by the Rates or Assessments to be made and assessed by virtue of this Act; and all and every the Contributor and Contributors upon the Credit of the said former Acts, for any such Annuity or Annuities as aforesaid, and his, her, or the;r respective Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, shall have, receive, enjoy, and be entitled by virtue of this Act, to have, receive, and enjoy the respective Annuity or Annuities so granted out of the said Races and Assessments by this Act appointed for the Purposes thereof as aforesaid, during the Term of the natural Life of the Persons nominated by each such Purchastr or Contributor as before mentioned, and for whose Life the said Annuities are respectively payable, and that all and every Person and Per-fohs who now is or are entitled to any such Annuity or Annuities as aforesaid, under the said former Acts, shall have good, sure, absolute, and in-defeasible Estates and Interests in the Annuity or Annuities so by him, her, or them respectively purchased according to the Tenor and true Meaning of the said former Acts; LXXVII. And be it further enacted, That where any Distress shall be made for any Sum or Sums of Money to be levied by virtue of this Act, the Distress itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor the Parties making the same be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers on account of any Defaulc or Want of Form in any Proceedings relating thereto, nor shall the Party or Parties distraining be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers ab initio% on account of any Irregularity which shall be afterwards done by the Party or Parties distraining, but the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity may recover full Satisfaction for the special Damage in an Action on the Cafe.

LXXVIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That no Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall recover in any Action for any such Irregularity, Trel'pafies, or other Proceedings, if Tender of sufficient Amends shall be made by or on Behalf of the Parties who shall have committed or caused to be commitied any such Irregularity, Trespass, or wrongful Proceedings before such Action brought, and in case no such Tender shall have been made it shall be lawful for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action, by Leave of the Court where such Action shall depend, at any Time before issue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he or they shall see fit, whereupon such Proceedings or Orders, and Judgements shall be had, made, and given in and by such Court as in other Actions where the Defendant is allowed to pay Money into Court.
