XXIII. And be it further enacted, That in every Cafe where any Wages, Debts due to or any other Sum or Sums of Money whatsoever, not exceeding the Sum of Persons un-Five Pounds, shall be due and owing to any menial Servant, Clerk, der Age to Book-keeper, Journeyman, Shopman, Shopwoman, Assistant, Labourers, certain1' or any other Person whomsoever, under the Age of Twenty-one Years, it Cases

shall and may be lawful to and for such Servant, Clerk, Book-keeper,

Journeyman, Shopman, Shopwoman, AiTiPtant, Labourer, or other Person, to sue for and recover such Debt in the said Court, in the same Manner as il he or she were of full Age; and the said Commissioners present in the said Court, are hereby authorized and required to take Cognizance of, and proceed concerning such Debts, in the same Manner, and shall have such and the fame Powers in regard thereto, as if the Plaintiff or Plaintiff's were of full Age.

XXIV. And be it further enacted, That no Person or Persons whomso- Imprison-ever, who shall be committed to the said Gaols or Houses of Correction, by mer t ot order of the said Court, for any Debt or Debts, shall be kept or continued in Custody, on any Pretence whatsoever, (except in Cases herein-after provided imitc for,) for any longer Space or Spaces of Time, from the Time of his, her oy

{Loc. &? fer.} 9 A their

830

47° GEORGII III. Se(T.2.r. Cap. 39*.

their Commitment to Prison, than is or are herein-after limited in 'that Behalf, (that is to say,) where the Debt (exclusive of Colts,) does not exceed the Sum of Twenty Shillings, then he, she, or they shall not be kept or continued in Custody for more than Twenty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Colts,) is above Twenty Shillings, and does not exceed Forty Shillings, then no more than Forty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Colts,) is above Forty Shillings, and does not exceed Three Pounds, then not more than Sixty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Colts,) is above Three Pounds, and does not exceed Four Pounds, then not more than eighty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Colts,) is above Four Pounds, then not more than One hundred Days, from the Time of his, her, or their Commitment; and the said Keeper or Keepers of the said Gaols or Houses of Correction is and are hereby directed and required to discharge such Persons accordingly.

XXV. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioners shall be, and they are hereby empowered, in their Order of Commitment of any Person or Persons to either of the said Common Gaols or Houses of Correction, for the Non-payment of any Debt or Debts, to order and direct such daily Sum or Sums to be paid weekly or otherwise, by the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs to the Defendant or Defendants so committed, for his, her, or their Maintenance while in Prison, as they, the said Commissioners, in their Discretion shall think proper, so as such daily Allowance shall not exceed Three-pence to each Person: And in default of Payment of the Sum or Sums so directed to be paid for the Space of Ten Days, the Keeper or Keepers of the said Gaols or Houses of Correction is, and are hereby directed to discharge such Person or Persons from his or their Custody, in such and the same Manner as if the full Debt and Colts, for which such Person or Persons was or were committed, had been fully paid and satisfied.

If any Debtor conceal Money or Goods the Time of Imprisonment shall be enlarged.

XXVI. And, in order the more effectually to prevent Persons summoned foi Debts to the said Court from' the fraudulent Concealment of their Money or Goods, be it enacted, That in case, upon the Summons of any Person for any Debt or Debts before the said Court, Information of any such Practice shall be given, such Court shall have Power to hear Evidence as to such fraudulent Concealment; and in case it shall be proved to their Satisfaction, upon the Oath of one or more Witness or Witnesses, (which Oath the said Court is hereby empowered to administer,) that any such Debtor has Money or Goods, which he or she has fraudulently and wilfully concealed, then, and in every such Case, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court to enlarge the aforesaid Time of Imprisonment to any Period in Addition thereto, not exceeding Three Calendar Months.

And the Time of Im-on for. rue at shall extend Separately and succes-fively for each Execution.

XXVII. And be it further enacted, That all and every Person and Persons who shall be taken in Execution, under or by virtue of any Process issuing from or out of the said Court of Requests, and who, at the Time of his, her, or their being taken into Custody, or during his, her, or their Imprisonment, shall have more than one Execution against him, her, or them in the said Court, shall beimprisoned the Time by this Act limited for and in respect of such Execution; and after the Time so limited in the first Execution is expired, the Imprisonment in the second Execution shall commence; and after the Time so limited on the second Execution is expired, the Imprisonment on the third Execution shall commence, and so on until

XIVIII. And be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful to and for the said Commissioners, to issue any Process against the Body or Bodies of any Person or Persons, in any Case or Cases where the Party or Parties entitled to any Order, Judgement, or Decree, shall at the same Time have obtained any Warrant or Process against the Goods and Chattels of the same Person or Persons.

Court, or shall hinder or obstruct the Proceedings of the said Court, then, and in every such Case, it shall and may be lawful to and for the Serjeant or Serjeants of the said Court, with or without the Assistance of any other Person or Persons, by the Order of the said Commissioners, to take such Offender or Offenders into Custody; and the said Commissioners shall examine into such Insult, Abuse, or Misbehaviour, either from their own View or Knowledge of what passed, or by the Oath or Oaths of one or more credible Witness or Witnesses; and upon such Insult, Abuse, or Miffie-haviour, being proved as aforesaid, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Commissioners, and they are hereby authorised and empowered to impose a Fine not exceeding Ten Pounds on each and every such Offender or Offenders; and in case such Fine shall not be forthwith paid. XXXIV And, for removing all Doubts whether the Statute of Liinita- Stitute of tionsmay be pleaded in the said Court of Requells, it is hereby further enacted Liniutio# and declared, That all Defendants in the said Court shall be allowed to plead or claim the Benefit of any Statute of Limitation in force and effect j and every Defendant, so pleading or claiming, shall have and receive such and the like Advantage and Relief thereby as such Defendant would have been entitled to, in case this Act had not been made, and he, she, or they had been sued for the fame Debt, or other Cause of Action, in any of His Majesty's Courts of Record at Westminster, or any other Court, and had there pleaded such Statute in bar to the Action or Suit.

XXXV. XXXVII. Provided always, That the said herein-beforerecited Act of the Third Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, and all Powers, Provisoes, Clauses, Matters, and Things therein respectively contained, shall, so far as the same are not hereby expressly repealed or otherwise provided for, and are not inconsistent with any of the Provisions of this present Act, continue and be in full Force, and extend to all and every Person and Persons to whom this Act doth or shall extend.

XXXVIII. And be it further enacted, That the said recited Act, and all and every the Powers, Provisions, Provisoes, Clauses, and Enactments therein contained, (save and except such Parts thereof as are hereby varied, altered, or repealed,) shall be as good, valid, and effectual for carrying this Act into Execution, as if the fame were repeated and re-enacted in this Act; and all and every the Powers, Provisions, Provisoes, Clauses, and Enactments herein, and in the said recited Act contained, (save and except such Parts thereof as are hereby varied, altered, or repealed)) shall extend to the said several Parishes, Hamlets, and Places of Westwood, Bromham and Hawheridge, all in the said County of Wilts, as well as to the said several Hundreds aforesaid.

4

XXXIX. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

XL. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall commence and take place on the said Second Monday next after the passing thereof.

An Act for the more easy and speedy Recovery of Small Debts within the Town of Gravesend and the Hundreds of Toltingtrough, Dartford, Wilmington, and Axiom, in the County of Kent.

[ill August 1807.]

WHEREAS the Town of Gravesend (comprising the Parishes of Gravesend and Milton) is much connected in Trade and Business with the several other Parishes and Places in the Hundreds of Toltingtrough, Dartford and Wilmington, and Axtane, in the County of Kent \ and the Inhabitants and Trade of the said Town, and of the said Parishes and Places respectively, have of late Years very much increased, and many Persons resort to the said Town from mod Parts of the United Kingdom, and from Foreign Countrirs: And whereas the Merchants, Tradesmen, and Inhabitants of the said Town, and Parishes and Places respectively, are, for the Purpose of recovering imall Debts under the respective Jurisdictions to which by the Common Law they niufl at present reforr, obliged to be at an Expence sometimes far exceeding, and in all Cases highly disproporticned to, the Value of the Sum in corned;: And whereas it would greatly tend to the Improvement and Encouragement of Trade, and to the necessary Support and Protection of useful Credit in the said Town, and in the several Parishes and Phces within the said several Hundreds, were sufficient [Lee. XI. And be it further enacted, That in case any Person or Per-attending if fons, redding or being within the Jurisdiction of the said Court, after furamoned. having been duly Served with a Subpoena or Summons, to be issued by the Clerk or Clerks of the said Court of Requests, or his or their Deputy, and paid or tendered hi', her, or their reasonable Expences, to attend and give his, her, or their Evidence, at a Time and Place in such Subpoena or Summons mentioned, on Behalf'of any Plaintiff or Defendant, shall neglect or refuse to appear pursuant to such Subpoena or Summons, due Proof being made of the Service of such Subpcrna or Summons, and no sufficient Cause for his, her, or their Absence or Non-appearance being shewn to the Satisfaction of the said Court on Oath, or, in case of being a Quaker or Quakers, solemn Affirmation being made (which Oath or Affirmation the said Commissioners, or any Three or more of them, are hereby authorised and required to administer), before the said Commissioners by the Party or Parties at whose Inltance and on whose Behalf such Subpsena or Summons issued, that the Person or Persons served therewith was or were a Witness, by such Party or Parties judged necessary for the Proof of his, her, or their Cause or causes, Action or Actions, Complaint or Complaints, Defence or Defences; or if the Person or Persons so served with such Subpooena or Summons shall appear, and refuse to be sworn, or, being a Quaker or Quakers to make Affirmation (which Oath or Affirmation the said Commissioners, or any Three or more of them, are hereby authorised and required to administei), or to give Evidence touching the Matter in question, then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Commissioners to impose any Fine not exceeding Fifty Shillings on such Person or Persons; and in case such Fine shall not be paid forthwith, such Fine shall and may be levied by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Offender or Offenders, by Warrant under.the Hands and, Seals of the said Commissioners, rendering the Overplus (if any) after deducting such Fine, and the Costs and Charges of such Distress and Sale, to the Owner or Owners of such Goods and Chattels; and such Fine when so paid, levied, or recovered, shall be paid over to the Party or Parties at whose Instance or on whose Behalf such Subpoena or Summons shall have been issued; and in case sufficient Distress shall not be found, it shall and may be lawful to and for any Three or more of the said Commissioners, by Warrant under their Hands and Seals, to commit such Offender to some one of the Common Gaols or Houses of Correction within the Western Division of the said County of Kent, for any Time not exceeding the Space of Two Calendar Months.

XXIII. And be it further enacted, That in case it shall at any Time during the Hearing of any Cause in the said Court appear by the Oath of any Person or Persons to the Satisfaction of the major Part of the Commissioners present at the Court at which such Cause shall be heard, that such Debtor or Debtors is or are unable, from bickness or unavoidable Accident, to pay and discharge the Debt or Debts for which he, she, or they shall have been so summoned, then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the major Part of the said Commissioners assembled at any such Court or Courts as aforesaid, to suspend orfuper-fede the Proceedings in such Cause, until it shall, upon like Proof as aforesaid, appear to the Court that such Debtor or Debtors shall be able to pay such Debt or Debts, and then to proceed again in Manner aforesaid, any Thing herein contained to the contrary thereof 4in anyvufe notwithstanding.

-S3CfV: And be it further enacted, That in every Cafe where any Wages or any other Sum or Sums ot Money whatsoever, not exceeding the Sum of Five Pounds, shall be due and owing to any menial Servant, Clerk, Book-keeper, Journeyman, Shopman, Shopwoman, Assistant, Labourer, or any other Person whomsoever, under the Age of Twenty-one Years, it shall and may be lawful to and for such Servant, Clerk, Book-keeper, Journeyman, Shopman, Shopwoman, Assistant, Labourer, or other Person, to sue for and recover such Debt in the said Court, in the same Manner as if he or she were of full Age; and the said Commissioners present in the said Court are hereby authorised’ and required to take Cognizance^ of and proceed in all causes concerning such Debts in the same Manner, and shall have such and the fame Powers in regard thereto, as if the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs were all of full Age.

XXXII. And be it further enacted, That no Person or Persons whom, soever shall be committed to Prison by Order of the said Court for any Debt or Debts, or kept or continued in Custody on any Pretence whatsoever (except in the Cases hereinafter provided for) for any longer Space or Spaces of Time from the Time of his, her, or their Commitment to Prison than is or are hereinafter limited (that is to say) where the Debt fexcb five of Colts)d6es not exceed the Sum of Twenty Shillings then he, she, or they shall not be kept or continued in Custody for more than Twenty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Colls) is above Twenty Shillings, and does not exceed Forty Shillings, then not more than Forty Days, and where the Debt (exclusive of Cods) is above Forty Shillings and does not exceed Three Pounds, then not more than Sixty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Cods) is above Three Pounds, and does not exceed Four Pounds then not more than Eighty Days; and where the Debt (exclusive of Cods) is above Four Pounds, and does not exceed Five Pounds, then not more than One hundred Days from the Time of his, her, or their Commitment; and the said Keeper or Keepers of tire said Gaol or Prison is and are hereby directed and required to discharge such Persons accordingly,

XXXIV. And, in order the more effectually to prevent Persons summoned for Debt to the said Court from fraudulently concealing their Money, Goods or Effects; be it therefore enacted, That in case, upon the Summons of any Person for any Debt or Debts before the said Court, Information of any such fraudulent Concealment shall be given, such Court shall have Power to hear Evidence as to the Fact; and in case it shall he proved to their Satisfaction upon the Oath of One or more credible Witness or Witnesses (which Oath the said Court is hereby empowered to administer), then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court toenlarge the aforesaid Timeof Imprisonment of such Debtor to any Period in Addition thereto not exceeding Three Calendar Months.

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That all and every Person and Persons who shall be taktn in Execution; under or by virtue of any Proofs iHu.ng frein or <. nt of the said Court of Requells, and who at the Tim. of his, her, or their being taken into Custody, or during his, her, or their Imprisonment, shall have more than one Execution against him, her or thun in the said Courr, shall be imprisoned the Time by this Act limited lor arid in respect of such Execution, and after the Time so limited in the first Execution is expired the Imprisonment on the Second Execution shall commence, and aiter the Time so limited on the Second Execution is expired the Imprisonment on the Third Execution shall commence, and so on until he, she, or they shall have been imprisoned the Time by this Act limited for and in respect of each Separate Execution to be issued against him, her, or them in the said Court previous to his. her, or their being taken into Custody, or during his, her, or their Imprisonmtnr; any Law, Statute, or Usage to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding.

Cap. 41.

An Act for continuing Three Acts, of the Sixth Year of King George the First, in the Twentieth Year of King George the Second, and in the Seventeenth Year of His present Majesty, for laying a Duty of Two Pennies Scots, or One-sixth Part of a Penny Sterling, upon every Scots Pint of Beer or Ale vended or sold within the Town of Burntisland and Liberties thereof, in the County of Fife, and for increasing the public Revenue of the said Town.

[1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of

King George the First, intituled, An Act for laying a Duty of 6 G. 1. Two Pennies Scots, or One-sixth Part of a Penny Sterling, upon every Scots Pint of Beer or Ale vended or sold within the Town of Bumt-island and Liberties thereof, for increasing the public Revenue of the said Town, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, whereby a Duty of Two Pennies Scots, or the Sixth Part of a Penny Sterling (over and above the Duty of Excise) was laid upon every Scots Pint of Ale and Beer brewed, brought in, vended, tapped, or fold within the Town of Burntisland and Liberties thereof, the said Duty to be applied to the Purposes, and levied in Manner mentioned in the said Act, which was to have Continuance from the Twenty-fourth Day of June One thousand seven hundred and twenty, for the Term of Twenty-five Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament: And whereas by another Act, passed id [Lor. its Per.] 9 / the

the Twentieth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, intituled, An Act for reviving and continuing an Act, passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the First, intituled, An Act for laying a Duty of Two Pennies Scots, or One-sixth Part of a Penny Sterling, upon every Scots Pint of Beer or Ale vended or sold within the Town of Burniiflaud or Liberties thereof for increasing the public Revenue of the said Town, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, the said former Act, and all the Duties, Powers, Authorities, and Clauses therein contained (except such as are thereby altered and varied) were revived and made payable, and continued in full Force and Lfleft, from and after the Twenty-fourth Day of June One thousand seven hundred and forty-seven, for and during the further Term of 1 hjrty.one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament: And whereas by another Act, passed in the Seventeenth Year of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for continuing Two Acts, made in the Sixth Year of the Reign of King George the First, and in the Twentieth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty, for laying a Duty of Two Pennies Scots, or One-sixth Part of a Penny Sterling, upon every Scots Pint of Beer or Ale vended or sold within the Town of Burnt-island and Liberties thereof for increasing the public Revenue of the said Town, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, the said former Acts, and all the Duties, Powers, and Authorities therein contained, were further continued and made payable for the Term of Thirty-one Years, from and after the Expiration of the Term gr anted by the said last-mentioned Act, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament: And whereas the Purposes for which the said Duty was granted and continued cannot be completed within the Term given by the said Acts (which have now but afjiortTinre to run); and as a Prolongation of the said Acts would be of great Advantage to the Community of the said Borough of Burntisland, and to the Public; may it therefore please Your Majesty that k may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the imposition or Duty granted and made payable by the said Acts, upon Ale or Beer that shall be either brewed, brought in, vended, tapped, or fold within the said Town and Privileges thereof, shall, from and after the Expiration of the Term granted by the said lall-recited Act, made in the Seventeenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, be further continued, raised, levied, collected, paid, and made payable to the Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council of the Borough of Bumt-island, and their Successors in Office, for the Time being, and their Assigns, or to such Collectors or Receivers as shall at any Time, during the Continuance of this present Act, be by them, or the major Part of them, appointed and empowered, for the Use of the Community of the said Burgh.

II. Provided always, and be it enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That no Person residing within the said Borough of Burniifiand or Liberties thereof, shall at any Time, during the Continuance of this Act, beJiable in Payment of or chargeable with the aforesaid Duty by this Act laid and made payable, for any Quantity or Quantities of Ate or Beer brewed by such Person for the private Use of his or her own Family, and not for Sale,' unless such Person be an actual Brewer of Ale or Beer for Sale, tir a Vender, Tapper, or Seller of Ale or Beer, any Thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

III. And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That the aforesaid Imposition or Duty (hah, during the Term herein-after mentioned, be raised, levied, and collected from the same Persons, and by the fame Means and Methods, and under the same Penalties and Forfeitures, and be accounted for, paid, and applied to and for the same Uses and Purposes; and that the Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council, and their Successors, for the Time being, be and continue Trustees for such Application, with the fame Powers, and subject to the same Rules and Directions, as are mentioned and prescribed in the said recited Acts; and that the said Acts, and every Article, R.ule, Clause, Matter, and Thing therein contained, shall be of the fame Force and Effect, to all Intents and Pu'poses, for raising, collecting, securing, and levying the said Imposition or Duty, and for applying the same to the Uses and Purposes mentioned in the said Acts, so far as thele are not already executed, for and during the additional 1 erm of Years for which the same are hereby granted, as if the said above recited Acts were particularly and at large repeated and re-enacted in the Body of this present Act, except as is herein-after mentioned.

IV. And be it further enacted by the Authority1 aforesaid, That from and after the Commencement of this present Act, and during the Continuance thereof, it shall not be lawful for any Brewer or Seller of Ale or Beer, living or carrying on his or her Brewery without the said Borough of Burntisland and Liberties thereof, to import or fell any Beer or Ale into or in the said Borough and Liberties thereof, unless, he, (lie, or they do previously give Notice to the Magistrates of the said Borough, or their Collector of the said Duty, at his Office or Dwelling House, and agree to be subjected to and charged with the Payment of the said Duty, for all the Beer and Ale which shall be brewed by such Brewer or Seller of Beer or Ale, living or carrying on his or her Brewery without the said Borough or Liberties thereof, for and during the Space of one whole Year next after and immediately following the Date of such Notice and Agreement made to and with the Magistrates of the said Borough of Burntisland, or their said Collector, and so long thereafter as such Brewer or Seller of Ale or Beer shall continue to import or fell Ale or Beer into or in the said Borough, and Liberties thereof, without having given such previous Notice, and agreed as aforesaid, being thereof duly convicted before any Two or more of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace, shall be charged with and liable to the Payment of the said Duty to the Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council of the said Borough, or their Collector, for all Ale or Beer brewed by him or her for the Space of Twelve Calendar Months immediately preceding his or her committing such Offence, and thereafter so long as he or she shall continue to import or fell Ale or Beer into or in the said Borough, within the aforesaid Term of Years for which the present Term is granted.

An Act for building a Bridge over the River ‘Thames, from the Parish of Sutton Courtney in the County of Berks, to the Parish of Culham in the County of Oxford. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS the building of a Bridge over the River Thames f'om the Parish of Sutton Courtney in the County of Berks, to the opposite Shore in the Parish of Culbam in the Count) of Oxford, at or near a Place called Culbam Ferry, or Culbam Ford, would greatly facilitate the Communication between the Counties of Berks and Oxford, and be of great Utility and Advantage to the Publick: And whereas the several Persons herein-after named are willing and desirous, at their own Cods, to build the said Bridge, and to keep the fame in Repair: but the Purposes aforesaid cannot be effected without the Aid of Parliament; May it therefore please Your Majesty, That it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this Adf, William Allnutt, John Batchelor Proprietor*. XXXII. And be it further enacted, That at the First General Meeting of the said Company of Proprietors herein-before directed to be held, the Proprietors there assembled, or Three or more of such Proprietor', shall chuse not less than Three Persons for the Time being Proprietors of the said Undertaking, which Persons so chosen shall be a Committee to manage, direct, and carry on the building of the said Bridge, and the Affairs and Business of the said Proprietors, for the Year then next following, or until another Committee shall be appointed, and to do all Matters and Things whatsoever relat ng thereto, and particularly such Matters and Things as are by this Act diiefted to be don* by such Commifees, and as shall from Time to Time be ordered by such General or Special Meetings as aforesaid y and at the said First Meeting the said Proprietors or Three or more of them, shall also chuse and appoint a Treasurer, and also a Clerk, who shall attend the several Meetings of the said Company of Proprietors, and the Meetings of the said Committees, and make Entries of the Proceedings in proper Books to be kept by him for that Purpose, and do whatsoever shall be ordered at such Meetings respectively for the Purposes of this Act.

Cap. 44.

An Act to enable His Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, to grant Letters Patent for establishing a Theatre or Playhouse, under certain Restrictions, in the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick. [ 1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS a licensed Playhouse in the Town of Birmingham, in the County of Warwick, would be of Convenience to the said Town, and to Persons resorting the re: May it therefore please Tour Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That so much of an Act of Parliament, made in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King Georgs the Second, intituled, An Act to explain and amend to G 2 so much of an Act, made in the Twelfth Year of the Reign of 'guecn Anne, recited, intituled, ‘An Act for reducing the Laws relating to Rogues, Vagabonds,

‘ Sturdy Beggars, and Vagrants, into one Act of Parliament \ and for the Binniiv ‘ more effectual punishing such Rogues, Vagabonds, Sturdy Beggars, and ' Vagrants, and fending them whither they ought to be sent,’ as relates to common Players of Interludes; and as discharges or restrains all Persons from repie'enting any Entertainment of the Stage whatever in virtue of Letters Patent from His Majesty, or by Licence of the Lord Chamberlain of His Majesty's Houfrhold for the Time being, except within the Liberties of Westminster, or where His Majesty is residing for the Time being, be, and the fame is hereby repealed with rel'pett to the said Town of Birmingham; and that it shall and may be lawful for H's Majesty, His cs* Per.'] 9 T Heirs

Heirs and Successors, to grant Letters Patent for establishing a Theatre or Playhouse within the said down of Birmingham, with such Privileges, and under such Provisions and Regulations for the due and orderly conducting and managing the lame, as to His Majesty shall seem meet.

II. And be it further enacted, That within Two Months next after any Letters Patent shall have been obtained for establishing a Theatre or Playhouse, and in the Month of December in every subsequent Year, the Proprietors thereof shall appoint a Committee from among themselves, to confilt of not more than Seven, for the Management of the Concerns of the said Theatre or Playhouse; and that the Persons composing such Committee, or any One of them, shall and may sue and be lutd in any Court of Law or Equity, for any Debt due to or owing from the said Proprietors in respect of the said Theatre or Playhouse; and that it shall and maybe lawful for the said Committee from Time to lime to be appointed, to demand and recover of and from the Receiver or Treasurer, for the said Proprietors, in case he shall have any Money in his Hands belonging to the said Proprietors, all Sum and Sums of Money which shall be recovered against the said Committee or any One of them, and such Receiver or Treasurer is hereby required to pay the fame; and in case the Rents, Profits, and Produce of the said Theatre or Playhouse shall be infuiheient to pay and discharge the Debts which may be incurred by such Proprietors on account thereof, the Share and Shares of every Proprietor shall be chargeable with his Proportion thereof in Preference to any other Debt whatsoever; and that it shall and may be lawful for the Committee to be appointed in Manner aforesaid, or any One of them, to recover of and from such Proprietors of the said Theatre or Playhouse, his, her, or their Share or Proportion of any Sum or Sums of Money which may be paid by, or recovered from the said Committee or any One of them, on account of the said Theatre or Playhouse, and to sell and dispose of his, her, or their Share or Shares in the said Theatre or Playhouse, if it shall be found necessary for the Purpose of raising such Proportion of the Expences as aforesaid.

III. And be it further enacted, That the Names and Places of Abode of the several Proprietors, who shall from Time to Time compose the Committee for managing the Concerns of the said Theatre or Playhouse, shall within Twenty-one Days next after they shall be so appointed, be inferred in some Newspaper to be published in the Town of Birmingham aforesaid.

IV. Provided always, and beitenafred, That the said Theatre or Playhouse, and the Management thereof, shall be under and subject to the Controul and Imptftion of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the County of Warwick for the Time being.

V. And it is hereby enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

Cap. 45.

An Act for amending an Act of the Twelfth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing and widening several Roads though the County of Lanark, and for building a Bridge over the River Clyde, at or near a Place called The Howford, in the said County and for making more effectual and converting the Statute Labour within the said County; and for repairing and regulating the Roads within the same.

[iff August 1807.]

Wife REAS the Laws now subsisting in Scotland for making Roads and building Bridges have been found insufficient in the County of Lanark, so that further Powers are necessary for carrying the Purposes of those Laws iDto Execution: And whereas the Provisions contained in an Act, passed in the Twelfth Year of His present Majesty's Reign, intituled, An Act for repairing and widening several Roads leading through the County ^Lanark, and for building a Bridge over the River Clyde, at or near a Place called The Howford, in the said Ccttnty, so far as the fame relates to the Statute Labour, or Conversion in lieu thereof, have been found in certain Respects inadequate and inapplicable, so that it is advisable to alter and amend the fame; and to declare more precisely than has been done hitherto what Persons are liable [Lee, L? XXXI. And be it further enacted, That no Person shall make or erect any House, or other Building, excepting only Stone Fences or Walls, not exceeding Six Feet in Height, within Twenty Feet of the Centre of any of the said Roads; and any Person so offending shall forfeit a Sum not exceeding Five Pounds Sterling for each Offence, to be recovered and applied as above directed; and the Persons so offending shall also be obliged, when ordered to do so by any Two or more Trustees, immediately to remove every such House or other Building; and upon their failing to do so within Thirty Days from the Time that a Notification in Writing has been given by any Two Trustees of the Encroachment, it shall be lawful for the Parish Trustees to order the said Buildings to be removed, and to charge Offenders with the F.xpence of doing so, to be recovered in the same Manner as other Forfeitures and Penalties, as above dtredfed,

And, in order to prevent the Misconduct of the Persons employed as Collectors of the said Tolls, be it further enacted, That every Person employed to collect any of the Tolls hereby granted and made payable, shall affix his Chridian and Surname on a Board on some conspicuous Part of the Toll House at which he shall be appointed to collect the said Tolls, on each and every Day that he shall continue in such Collection, under the Penalty of any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds for every Neg-led thereof; and if any such Collector shall wilfully misbehave hinffelfin the Collection of the said Tolls, or shall make Ule of any opprobrious or improper Language to any Person or Persons passing through any of the Turnpikes already erected or hereafter to be erected, by virtue of the said recited Acts, or either of them, or of this Act, and shall be thereof con-vided on his own Confession, or on the Oath of One or more credible Witness or Witnesses, before One or more of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the said County of Sussex, he shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding the Sum of Five Pounds nor less than Forty Shillings, and in Default of Payment thereof shall be committed to the Common Gaol or House of Correction, for any Time not exceeding One Calendar Month.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Sess. 2.

Cap. 48.

An Act for continuing and amending Two Act* of the Fifth and Twenty-sixth Years of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Great Grimsby Haven, at or near Upper Sand End, to Wold Newton Church, and from Nun s Farm to the Mill Field, in the Parish of Irby, in the County of Lincoln. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS by an Act paded in the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, inticuled. An Act for repairing and widening the Road from Great Grimsby Haven, at or near a Place called the Upper Sand End, to Wold Newton Church, and from Nun’s Farm to the Mill Field, in the Parish of I by, in the County of Lincoln, federal Toils and Powers were granted to Trustees for repairing the said Road during the Term therein mentioned: And whereas by another Act passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, the said first-mentioned Act was continued for a further Term, ana f mie of the Provisions were thereby altered and enlarged: And whereas, the Trusties appointed to put the said Acts in Execution, have in pursuance thereof borrowed considerable Sums of Money on the Credit and Security of the Tolls arising the reby, which with a considerable Arrtar of Interest thereon are itill doe and cannot be paid off, nor can the said Road be kept in Repair unless the said Acts be continued for a further Term; and it is expedient that some farther Powers and Authoriiits should be granted for that Purpol'e: May it therefore pleal'e Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s [Lw. fcf Per.^ 10 I most

An Act to amend and render more effectual To much of an Act, of the Thirty-third Year of his late Majesty, for draining certain Fen Lands in the Isle of Ely, and Counties of Suffolk and Norfolk, near Mildexhall River; and impowering the Con-fervaters of Bedford Level, to fell certain Fen Lands, as relates to the Lands in the Second District described in the said Act. XXVI. And be it further enacted, That the First Payment of the Rates or Taxes, hereby intended to be imposed, and all future Payments, Rates or Taxes, hereby imposed, shall be made at such Times and Places as the said Commissioners shall appoint, is otice thereof in Writing signed by their Clerk or some other Officer appointed by them, or any Seven or more of them,< having been affixed upon the Door of the Parish Church of Mildenhall Fourteen Days preceding; and a Year’s Tax shall become due on the Twenty-fourth Day of June One thousand eight hundred and eight.

XXVII. Provided always, and it is hereby further enacted, That this Act, or any Thing herein contained, shall not extend, or be construed to-extend, to invalidate, lessen, diminiffi, alter, or take away any of the Rights, Powers, and Authorities, vested in the Governor, Bailiffs, and Commonalty of the Company of Conservators of the Great Level of the Fens called Bedford Level; or in the said Governor, Bailiffs, and Conservators, by virtue of an Act made in the Fifteenth Year of the Reign of King Charles the Second, intituled, An Act for settling the Draining of the Great Level of the Fens called Bedford Level; or by virtue of any other Act, Statute, or Charter whatsoever; but that all Rights, Powers, and Authorities whatsoever which by virtue of the said Act of King Charles the Second, or of any other Act, Statute, or Chartsr whatsoever, now are vested in the said Governor, Bailiffs, and Commonalty, or in the said Governor, Bailiffs, and Conservators, or any of them, shall for ever hereafter remain, continue, and be in the said Governor, Bailiffs, and Commonalty, and in the said Governor, Bailiffs, and Con-Jervators, and every of them, as fully and amply, to all Intents and Purposes, as if this Act had never been made.

XXX. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and ffi.dl be judicially taken Notice ofas iueh by all Judges, Justicei, and others, without being tpecialiy pleaded.

XI. And whereas certain Parts of the said Roads, by the said recited Act intended to be amended, have already been, and other Part'- here-after may be diverted and rendered nearer and more commodious to the Public, and Doubts have arisen, and hereafter may arse, whethe. any particular Person or Persons liable to repair the old Highway or Road so deviated from, by Statute Duty- or by reason of che Tenure of their Lands, or otherwise, ought solely to repair the whole of the kme diverted or new line of Road, or only to contribute in some Proportion towards the Repair thereof jointly with the Inhabitants of the Parish, Township, Hamlet, Division or District respectively, wherein the said new Line of Road lies; for obviating which Doubts, and preventing Disputes in future, |be it further enacted, That the Person or Persons who was, were, or shall be liable as aforesaid, to the Repair of such old Highway or Road, which hath been or shall be so diverted or turned, shall respectively be and continue in the same Manner liable to the Repair of such new Road, cr so much thereof as shall be equal to the Burthen and Expence of the Repair of such old Highway or Road, from which they, he, or Ihe, have been, or shall be in anywise exonerated, by the diverting of_ such Road; and that the Inhabitants of every such Parish, Township,* Hamlet, Division, or District respectively, wherein the said new Line of Road shall lie, shall be liable to the Repair of the Remainder of Inch new Line of Road, and that if the several Parties interested cannot agree therein, the same shall be viewed by Two Justices of the Peace, acting within the Distiid where such Road lies, and shall be settled, adjusted, and determined by them in such Manner as they shall think just ;md reasonable, and from and after such Determination of the said Justices, the Inhabitants of the said Parish, Township, Hamlet, Division, or biftrid, and the Person or Persons liable to repair a certain Part of such new Road as aforesaid, respectively neglecting to repair the said new Road, according to such Adjustment as aforesaid, shall bear all Charges and Expences of ' Indictments and Prosecutions, which shall be brought against them respectively for not repairing their apportioned Part of the same.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO SEPTIMO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. ii.

An Act to continue and amend Three Acts, pasted in the Fifth, Seventh, and Twenty-sixth Years of His present Majesty, for repairing certain Roads therein mentioned, leading from Chatteris Ferry to the Town of Wisbech Saint Peters, in the Isle of Ely, and other Places in the said Acts mentioned.

nor can the said Roads be properly amended, improved and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Acts is continued, some of the Powers and Provisions of the said Acts altered, enlarged, and amended, and the Tolls increased; May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the said Acts passed in the Fifth, Seventh, and Twenty-sixth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, and all and every the Authorities, Powers, Privileges, Provisions, Penalties, Reservations, and Clauses therein contained (except such as relate to Exemption from Stamp Duties, and such as are hereby varied, altered, or repealed) shall be and continue in full Force for and during the Term hereinafter mentioned, as fully and effectually to all Intents and Purposes, as if the fame were herein particularly repeated and re-enacted, but subject nevertheless to the Amendment, Variations, Alterations, and Additions herein contained, and which shall commence and take effect upon the passing of th’13 Ad; and this Act, and the Additional Term and the Tolls hereby granted, (halt be and are hereby declared to be subject and liable to the Payment of all Money now due and owing upon the Credit or on Account of the said firmer Acts, or which may hereafter be borrowed or become due and owing on the Credit of the said former Acts and this Act, and of ail interest due and to grow due for the fame respectively.

II. And be it further enacted, That the Trustees named in or appointed in pursuance of the said recited Acts or any of them, shall be and are hereby appointed Trustees for putting in Execution this Act; and that the General Meetings of the said Trustees shall in future be held annually at the Town of Wisbech Saint Peters aforesaid; and that the said 1 ruf-tees shall be and are hereby empowered to adjourn themselves, from Time to Time, to such Time and Place, within the Limits of the said Roads, as they shall think proper; and in case no particular Adjournments shall be made by the said Trustees, then that all the Meetings of the said Trustees (except the said General Meetings) shall from Time to Time be held according to the Directions of the said recited Acts; Provided always, that no Trustee shall vote at any of the said Meetings on any Question wherein he shall be particularly concerned or interested.

IV. And whereas the Tolls granted and continued by the said Acts have been found insufficienc; be it therefore enacted, That from and after the Third Monday next after the passing of this Act, the said Tolls shall be and the same are hereby repealed; and that instead thereof there shall be demanded and taken, before any Horse, Cattle, or Carriage shall be permirttd to pass through any Gate or Turnpike now erected or hereafter to be erected on the said Roads, or on any Part thereof, such Tolls as the said Trustees, or any Seven or more of them shall from Time to Time appoint, no: exceeding the several and respective Sums herein-after mentioned; (that is to say),

For every Iiorfe, Mare, Gelding, Mule, or other Cattle, (except Oxen),

drawing any Carriage, the Sum of Four-pence Halfpenny

For every Chaise, Gig, or other Carriage of the like Drscription, drawn by a fTgle Horse, the Sum of Sixpence; and if drawn by Two Horses Nine-pence: ,

For every Yoke of Oxen drawing any Carriage, the Sum of Four-pence Halfpenny:

For every Horse, Mare, Gelding, Mule, or other Cattle, laden or unladen j and not drawing, the Sum of One-penny Halfpenny:

For every Drove of Oxen, Cows, or neat Cattle, the Sum of One Shilling and Three-pence per Score; and so in Proportion for any greater or less Number:

And for every Drove of Calves, Hogs, Swine, Sheep, or Lambs, the Sum of Seven-ptrce Halfpenny per Score; and so in Proportion for any greater cr left Number.

Which said several and respective Tolls hereby granted shall be and the same are hereby vested in the Trustees for executing the said Acts and this Act; and the fame and every Part thereof shall be collected, recovered, levied, paid, applied, assigned, lessened, varied, and disposed of, in such and the same Manner, and by such and the fame Ways and M ans, and with Lch. Powers, Provisions, Remedies, and Restrictions, as are contained in the said Acts respecting the Tolls thereby or by either of them authorized to be taken.

and all and every such Sum or Sums of Money as shall be advanced, botroved, or lent for Payment of the fame, and all Intered to grow due thereon, shall be paid out of the fird Money which shall arise or be received by virtue of the said Acts or of this Act, in Preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

XXII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and Publick Act, taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as

such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

XV. Provided always, and be it enacted, That where any Question shall arise, touching the Title of any Person to any Money to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery, in pursuance of this Act, for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or of any Estate, Right, or Interest in any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be purchased, in pursuance of the said recited Act, and this Act, or to any Bank Annuities to be purchased with any such Money, or the Dividends or Interest of any such Bank Annuities, the Person or Persons who shall have been in Possession of such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments at the Time of such Purchase, and all Persons claiming under such Person or Persons, or under the Possession of such Person or Persons, shall be deemed and taken to have been lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments,according to such Possession, until the contrary shall be shewn to the Satisfaction of the said Court of Chancery, and the Dividends or Interest of the Bank Annuities to be purchased with such Money, and also the Capital of such Bank Annuities, shall be paid, applied, and disposed of accordingly, unless it shall be made appear to the said Court, that such Possession was a wrongful Possession, and that some other Person

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That this Aft shall bedeemed and taken to be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by aJJJudges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

XIX. And be it further enacted, That, from and after the Second Monday Term of this next after the passing of this Act, the Term granted by the said recited Act shall cease and determine, and that from thenceforth the said recited Act (subject to the Alterations and Amendments herein contained) shall continue and be in force, and be executed for and during the further Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

An Act to continue the Term, and alter and enlarge the Powers of Two Acts, of the Sixth and Twenty-seventh Years of His present Majesty, for repairing and amending the Road from the present Turnpike Road, in the Parish of Hurjleyf in the County of Southampton, through the Borough of Andover to the Town of Newbury, in the County of Berks, and from Newbury to Chilton Pond and Newtown River. XVII. And be it further enacted, That all the Charges and Expences

of this Act 5 lining anc* pftkng this Act, shall be paid out of any Monies already

raised by virtue of the said recited Acts, or out of the first Monies to aril'e by vi tue of the said Acts and this Act, in preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

[Publick Act.]

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

Continuance

XIX. And be it further enacted, That the said Acts (subject to the at this Act. Alterations and Amendments herein contained) shall continue and be in Force, and be executed for and during the Residue now to come and

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign 5 G-of His present Majesty, intituled, "An Act for repairing and " widening the Road leading from a Street called The Hun-'< dred, at Romjey, through Chilworth, to the River at Swathling, in the " County of Southampton, and for connecting the fame with the Road " leading from the City of Winchester, through Hurfiey to Chandlers " Ford, and from Hurjley aforesaid to the Turnpike Road at Romsey " aforesaid; and also for repairing and widening the Road leading from " the River at Swathling aforesaid, through Botley to the Turnpike " Road at Shirriil Heath, in the said County of SouthamptonAnd 26 G whereas an Act was passed in the Twenty-sixth Year of His present Majesty's Reign, intituled, "An Act to continue the Term and Powers of an Act made in the Fifth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, so far as the fame relates to the repairing, and widening the Road leading from the River at Swathling, through Botley, to the Turnpike Road at Shirriil Heath, in the County of SouthamptonAnd whereas great Progress hath been made in the Execution of the said Act, so far as the lame relates to the said Road from the River at Swathling through Botley, to the Turnpike Road at Shirriil Heath, and considerable Sums of Money have been borrowed on the Credit of the Tolls authorized to be taken on the said Road; which Money cannot be paid off, nor can the said Road be effectually amended, improved, and kept in Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Acts, so far as che fame relates to the said last-mentioned Road, arc further continued , May it therefore please Your iLcc. & Per.] 11 P Majesty,

II. And be it further enacted, That no Toll shall be demanded or taken for any Waggons, Wains, Carts, Carriages, or Horses employed in carrying or conveying, or going to carry or convey, or returning from Carrying or conveying, having been employed only in carrying or conveying on the same Day any Stones, Bricks, Gravel, or other Materials for repairing of the said Road, or any of the Roads in the Townships or Parishes in which any Part of such Roads doth lie; or Hay, Straw, or Corn in the Straw only, not sold or disposed of, but passing to be laid up or placed in the Outhouses, or on the Lands of the Owners thereof; or for any Waggons, Wains, Carts, Carriages, or Horses employed in carrying or conveying, or going empty to carry or convey, or returning from carrying or conveying, having been employed only in carrying or conveying any Ploughs, Harrows, or Implements of Husbandry, or any Mould, Dung, Compost, or Manure employed in Husbandry for manuring or improving Lands, or for any other Thing employed in the Management of any Farm or Lands, or for any Horses or Cattle going to or leiurning from Pasture or Watering Places, or going to be or returning from being Ihoed or farried; or from any Person going to or returning from his proper Parochial Church, Chapel, or other Place of religin s Worship tolerated by Law, on a Sunday, or on any other Day on which Divine Service is ordered by Authority to be celebrated, or attending the funeral of any Person that shall die and he buried in any of the Parishes in which the said Roads lie; or from any Clergyman going to or returning from visiting any sick. Person, or upon other his Parochial or Ministerial Duty on a Sunday-, or on any other Day on which Divine Service is ordered by Authority to be celebrated or for any Horses, Cat'ie, or Carriages of whatsoever Description, employed or to be employed in conveying the Mails of Letters and Expresses under the Authority 01 His Majesty's Postmaster General, either when employed in conveying, r, ching, or guarding such Mails or Expresses, or in returning ba k :< m conveying the fame; or for any Elorles, Carts, or Waggons atrer.di.ig any Soldiers upon their March or on Duty, or drawing any Carnage attending them with their Arms or Baggage; cr for any Horse,. And be it further enacted, That all Persons who by Law are or Personsliabl* shall be liable to do Statute Work, or are or shall be chargeable towards to Statute repairing and amending the said Road leading from the River at Swath- '?’ork l. ling, through Botley to the Turnpike Road at Sbirrill Heath, or any Part w,th Repair* thereof, shall dill remain liable thereto in like Manner as heretofore j and of the Road, it shall be lawful for any Two or more Justices of the Peace for the County in which the said Road shall be situate, and they are hereby required and empowered, upon Application made to them by the said Trustees, or any Five or more of them, or by their Treasurer, Clerk, or Surveyor, Yearly to adjudge and determine what Part or Proportion of the Statute Work shall every Year be done upon the said Road by the Inhabitants of the respective Parishes, Townships, or Places in which the said Road doth lie 5 and also what Proportion of the Money received by the Surveyor or Surveyors of the Highways of every such Parish, Township, or Place, in lieu of or as a Composition for such Statute Work as aforesaid, shall be by him, her, or them, paid to the said Trustees or to their Treasurer or Treasurers; and out of such Lifts the said Justices shall and may allot, appoint, and order such and so many of the Persons who shall appear subject and liable to Statute Work as aforesaid, to do such Number of Days Stature Work in every Year upon the said Road as the said Justices shall think reasonable, and the same shall be done at such Days and at such Times (not being Hay-time or Harvest), and in such Pans of the said

VII. And be it further enacted, That in case the Person or Persons to whom any Sum or Sums of Money shall be awarded for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be purchased by virtue of the said recited Act and this Act, shall refule to accept the fame, or shall not be able to make a good Title to the Premises, to the Satisfaction of the said Trustees or any Five or more of them, or in case such Person or Persons to whom such Sum or Sums of Money shall be lb awarded as aforesaid cannot be found, or if the Person or Persons entitled to such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments be not known or discovered, then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Trustees or any Five or more of them, to order the said Sum or Sums of Money so awarded as aforesaid to be paid into the Bank of England in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery, to be placed to his Account, to the Credit of the Parties interested in the said Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments [defcriltng them], subject to the Order, Controul, and Dispoficion of the said Court of Chancery, which said Court of Chancery, on the Application of any Person or Persons making Claim to such Sum or Sums of Money, or any Part thereof, by Motion or Petition, shall be and is hereby empowered in a summary Way of Proceeding or otherwise, as to the said Court shall seem meet, to order the same to be laid out and inverted in the Publick Funds, and to order Distribution thereof, or Payment of the Dividends thereof, according to the respective Ertate or Effaces, Title, or Interest, of the Person or Persons making Claim thereunto, and to make such other Order in the Premises as to the said Court shall seem just and reasonable; and the Cashier or Cathiers of the Bank of England who shall receive such Sum or Sums of Money is and are hereby required to give a Receipt or Receipts for such Sum or Sums of Money, mentioning and specifying for what and for whole Ul'e the fame is or are received to such Person or Persons as shall pay any such Sum or Sums of Money into the Bank as aforesaid.

VIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That where any Question shall arise touching the Title of any Person to any Money to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery in pursuance of this Act, for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or of any Estate, Right, or Interest, in any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be purthaled in pursuance of the said recited Act and this Act, or to any Bank Annuities to be purchased with any such Money, or the Dividends or Interest of any such Bank Annuities, the Person or Persons who shall have been in Possession of such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments at the Time of such Purchase, and all Persons claiming under such Person or Persons, or under the Possession of such Person or Persons, shall be deemed and taken to have been lawfully entitled to such I-ands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, according to such Possession, until the contrary shall be shown to the Satisfaction of the said Court of Chancery; and the Dividends or Interest of the Bank Annuities to be

13 purchased

9 83

47° GEORGII III. Sess.2. Cap. 56.

purchased with such Money, and also the Capital of such Bank Annuities, shall be paid, applied, and dii'posed of accordingly, unless it shall be made appear to the said Court that such PoffdEon was a wrongful possession, and that some other Person or Persons was or were lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or to _some Estate or Interest therein.

IX. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That where by reason of any Dil'ability or Incapacity of the Person or Persons, or Corporation, entitled to any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be purchased under the Authority of the said recited Act and this Act, the Purchase Money for the same shall be required to be paid into the Court of Chancery, and to be applied in the Purchase of other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments to be settled to the like Uses in pursuance of the said recited Act and this Act, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court of Chancery to order the Expences of all Purchases from Time to Time to be made in pursuance of the said recited Act and this Act, or so much of such Expences as the said Court shall deem real'onable, to be paid by the said Trustees, or any Five or more of them, out of the Monies to be received by virtue of the said Acts and this Act, who shall from Time to Time pay such Sums of Money for such Purposes as the said Court shall direct.

X. And be it further enacted, That all the Costs and Charges incident to and attending the obtaining and passing this Act shall be paid out of the Money collected and received or to be collected and received by virtue of the said Acts or this Act, upon the said Road from the River at Swathlirg through Botley, to the Turnpike Road at Sherrill Heath, in preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

XI. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

XII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall commence upon the passing thereof, and shall continue and be in force, and be executed for and during the Residue now to come and unexpired of the Term granted and continued by the said Acts, and from the Expiration thereof for and during the further Term of Twenty-one Years; and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

The Court of Chancery may order reasonable Expences of Purchases to be paid by Trullees.

subject nevertheless to the Rules, Orders, and Directions mentioned and contained in the said recited Act, except in such Cases where the same are hereby varied or altered.

XVI. And be it further enacted, That once at leail in each and every Year during the Execution of this Act (such Year to be computed from the Day of the passing thereof) the said Commissioner shall, and he is here-by required to make a true and just Statement or Account of all and every Sum and Sums of Money by him received and expended, or due to him for his own Trouble and Expences in the Execution of this and the said recited Act; and such Statement or Account, when so made, together with the Vouchers relating thereto, shall be by him laid before any Two of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace for the Time being for the said County of Flint, or the County of Denbigh (not interested in the said intended Division and Inclosure) to be by them examined ana balanced; and such Balance shall be by such Justices stated in the Book of Accounts to be kept in the Office of the Clerk to the said Commissioner, and no Charge or Item in such Accounts shall be binding on the Parties concerned, or valid in Law unless the same shall have been duly allowed by such Justices.

XVII. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioner shall be allowed the Sum of Two Pounds and Two Shillings for every Day that he shall be actually employed in any Business required of him as Commissioner by the said recited Act, or this Act, including Days of necessary travelling, as well as others, in full Satisfaction for his Time, Trouble, and Expences, respecting such Business.

XX. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That in case it shall happen that the same Person or Persons is or are seised of Messuages, Lands, or Hereditaments for Life only, and of the Fee-Simple and Inheritance of other Messuages, Lands, or Hereditaments, within the Laid District or Franchise, and any other Person or Persons having or claiming to have Rights or Interests in the Lands and Grounds hereby intended to be divided, and shall be entitled, or claim to be entitled to Right of Common in respect of both such Estates; then and in such case the Commissioner, upon the Request, in'Writing, of such Person or Persons, or of his, her, <5r their Agent or Attorney, shall set out and allot the Share or Proportion of such Person or Persons in respect of his, her, or their different Estate in distinct and separate Parcels from each other, so that the Portion of Common awarded in respect of the Messuages, Lands, or Hereditaments held for Life, or settled Estate, be no way intermixed with, but kept separate from, the Portion awarded in respect of the unsettled Estate.

XXL And, for the more just and regular Division, Allotment, and Distribution of the said Common Marshes, Waite Low Lands, and other Commons and Waste Lands by this Act directed to be divided, allotted, and inclosed, be it further enacted, That the said Commissioner shall, and he is hereby required, as soon as conveniently may be after the passing of this Act, to value all the Lands and Grounds by this Act directed to be divided, allotted, and inclosed; and also all the ancient inclosed Lands and Grounds having Right of Common over the fame, which Valuation, and the Particulars thereof, shall be reduced into Writing and signed by the said Commissioner, and shall be lodged with the Clerk to the said Commissioner for the Inspection of the several Proprietors or their Agents, and any Person or Persons so interested shall be entitled to a Copy of such Valuation on demand, paying for such Copy a reasonable Price to be ascertained by the said Commissioner; and the said Commissioner shall give or cause to be given Fourteen Days Notice, to be affixed upon the principal outer Door of the Parish Church of Rhuddlan aforesaid, upon some Sunday during or immediately after Divine Service, of the Time and Place by him appointed for receiving and hearing any Objections that may be made to such Valuation or Quality; and the said Commissioner shall hear and determine all such Objections, and his Determination therein shall be final.

XXII. Provided always, That nothing in this Act contained shall extend or be construed to extend, to defeat, lessen, or abridge the Powers vested in the Commissioners appointed in and by the said Act of the Thirty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, herein-before mentioned, for putting such Act into Execution.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO SEPTIMO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

An Act for inclosing Lands at Thorpe, in the County

WHEREAS there are within the Manor and Parish of Thorpe, in the County of Surrey, divers Open and Common Fields, Common Meadows, Pastures, Lammas Lands, and Waste Grounds, containing together, by Computation, Eight hundred Acres, or thereabouts, and also divers inclosed Lands and Grounds, containing by Computation Six hundred Acres, or thereabouts: And whereas the King’s most Excellent Majesty in Right of His Crown is seised of a certain Piece or Parcel of Land called the Ten Acres Piece, lying in Tiorpe aforesaid, and Richard Wyatt of Egham, in the said County of Surrey, Esquire, is the LefP-e thereof: And whereas John Leigh Bennett Clerk, is Lord of the Manor of Thorpe, and as such is entitled to the Right of Soil in, over, and upon the several Commons and Waste Lands within thr said Manor: Anil whereas the said John Leigh Bennett is Impropii-ate Rt stor of the Rectory and Parish Church of Thorpe aforesaid, and also Vitar of Thorpe aforesaid, and as such is entitle;! to the Great and Small Tythes arising or renewing within the said Parish, except as to certa n Lands called Northlands, and Mead lake, which are subject to the Payment of certain Moduf-s in lieu thereof to the said John Leigh Benr.ett: Ar.d whereas the said John Leigh Bennett, the President and Scholars of Corpus Chrish College in Oxford, and their Lessee, Sir William Blackett Baronet, James Ludivick Grant Esquire, and others, are Owners and Proprietors of all the said Open Common Fields, Common Meadows, Pastures, Lammas Lands, and Waste Grounds intended to be divided and inclosed as herein-after mentioned: And whereas an Act was passed in the [L°c. And be it further enacted, That each of the said Commissioners and Umpire shall be allowed and paid by the said Proprietors the Sum of Two Pounds and Two Shillings, and no more, for every Day which he shall attend 3nd be employed at any Meeting or Meetings, or tn going to or returning from thence, or otherwise howsoever, in executing the Powers and Authorities hereby given to them, which said Sum of Two Pounds and Two Shillings shall be inclusive of all Expences whatsoever incurred by going to, or returning from, or attending at any such Meeting or Meetings.

An Act for inclosing Lands in the Manor and Townftftp

of Bramham, in the West Riding of the County of York. [1st August 1807.]

WHEREAS there are within the Manor and Township of Bramham in the West Riding of the County of York, certain Common Town Fields, containing together by Estimation Six hundred and eighty Acres or thereabouts; and certain Commons or Wastes containing together Six hundred and fifty Acres or thereabouts: And whereas. Sir Thomas Gascoigne Baronet is Lord of the Manor of Bramham aforesaid, and entitled to the Soil of all the said Commons and Waste Grounds, and to all the Royalties belonging to the said Manor (subject to a Claim made by the Right Houourable Charles Lord Headley, to the Soil of a certain Parcel of Waste Ground called the Open Rakes, containing by Estimation Fifty Acres or thereabouts): And whereas the said Sir Thomas Gascoigne, Charles Lord Headley, James Fox Esquire, Eleanor Eamonfon Widow, the Reverend Robert Bowtias Clerk, and several other Persons are Owners and Proprietors of Mef* fuages and Cottages, or Scites of Messuages and Cottages, Lands and Grounds within the said Manor and Township, and entitled to Right of Common upon the said Commons and Waste Grounds, and to Right of Average in the said Fields; and the said Sir Thomas Gascoigne is all'o en-tided to and hath heretofore enjoyed Right of Coney Warren upon the [Lee. & Per.] 13 C said

Lord of tha Manor.

provided that the Defendant or Defendants in every such Action, shall be by the said Commissioners reimbursed all the Costs, Charges, and Expences which he or they shall reasonably pay, expend, or be put unto in the Defence of such Adiqn or Actions, by and out of the Money to be raised for carrying this Act into Execution.

XV. And be it further enacted, That all subsisting Leases and other

Agreements at Rack Rent of all or any Part or Parts of the said Lands and Grounds so intended to be divided and inclosed, shall immediately after such Lands and Grounds respectively shall be set out or allotted, or as soon after as the said Commissioners shall by their Award direct, cease, determine, and be void, (in case the Lessors and Lessees do not otherwise agree amongst themselves); and the respective Owners or Proprietors of the Lands or Grounds comprised in such Leases or Agreements respectively, or any Part or Parts thereof, shall make such Satisfaction to their respective Lessees or Tenants, for any Loss or Prejudice they may respectively sustain thereby, as the said Commissioners shall adjudge or ascertain, by Writing under their Hands, as a reasonable Recompence to be paid to such Lessees or Tenants, by Way of Equivalent for their respective Terms therein. XVI. And be it further enacted, That all and every the Closes and Inclosed Lands and Grounds whatsoever, which, on or before the First Day of January One thousand eight hundred and six, were so inclosed from the said Common Town f ields, shall be taken and considered as Old Inclosure, and shall be free and clear of and from all Manner of Stray and Rights of Common and Average, in, upon, or over the fame, unless the respective Owner or Owners, Proprietor or Proprietors thereof, shall consent and agree that the same shall be deemed and taken by the said Commissioners to be Open Field Land, and shall permit tire fame to be divided and allotted as such by virtue and in pursuance and according to the Directions of this Act; and that all Encroachments and Inclosures made from the said Commons and Waites, within the said Manor and Township within Twenty Years next before the passing of this Act, shall be deemed and considered as Part of the said Commons and Wastes, and shall be allotied by the said Commissioners accordingly: But, nevertheless, the said Commissioners shall and they are hereby authorized to allot the said Encroachments to the several Persons in the Possession thereof, in Part of their several Allotments, such Encroachments to be estimated at their unimproved Value only, without Regard to any Buildings or other Improvements made thereon.

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioners shall and may, and they are hereby authorized, to set out, award, and allot such Part or Parts of the Lands and Grounds hereby directed to be divided and inclosed as they shall judge most fit and proper for Watering Places for Cattle, and for Common Pits for getting Stoiles, Gravel, Sand, and other Materials for repairing the Highways within the said Township of Bramham, and for such other Purposes as the said Commissioners shall award and direct, not exceeding Five Acres; and that the same shall remain for the Use of the Inhabitants thereof for the Time being for ever, for the Purposes aforesaid; and that the Herbage growing thereon, and also the Herbage of the Public Carriage Roads within the said Township, after the Execution of the Award of the said Commissioners herein-after directed, shall be and are hereby vefledin the Surveyors of the Highways of the said Township of Bramham for the Tim£ being, in Trull to let the fame for the bell Rent or Rents that can be gotten, ftnd to apply such Rents in repairing the Public Highways and Roads within the said Township, they the said Surveyors accounting with the Inhabitants thereof touching the Application of such* Rents at the Time of settling their annual Accounts.

And whereas some Parts of the Arable and Pasture Lands within the said Parish of Shipdbam, comprised in certain Fields, called North Field, Mill Field, Little Field, Low Field, Three Acre Field, and Silver Field, he intermixed, and are inconveniently situated for the respective Owners and Occupiers thereof; be it therefore enacted, that the said Commissioners shall, and they are hereby authorized and required to allign, set out, and allot the said intermixed Lands, or any other Lands within the said Parish of Shipdbam, of equal Value in lieu thereof, unto and among ft the several Owners and Proprietors of the said intermixed Lands, in such Manner and in such Proportions as the said Commissioners shall adjudge and determine to be equivalent to, and a full Compensation for their several Parts and Shares of the said intermixed Lands comprized within the before-mentioned Fields.

or who shall be beyond the Seas, or otherwise disabled to act for themselves, himself, or herself (such Consent to be testified in Writing under the common Seal of the Body Politick, Corporate, or Collegiate, and under the Hands of the other consenting Parties respectively) and all and every such Exchange or Exchanges so made shall be good, valid, and effectual in the Law to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever: Provided nevertheless, that no Exchange shall be made of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments,

XLI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall extend, or be construed to extend, to revoke, make void, alter, or annul any Will, Settlement, or Surrender, or to prejudice any Person or Persons having any Estate, Right, or Claim of Dower, Jointure, Portion, Debt, Rent, or Incumbrance out of, upon, or affecting any of the Messuages, Cottages, Lands, or Tenements, within the said Parish of Shipdbam, or out of, upon, or affecting any other Messuages, Cottages, Lands, or Tenements in any adjoining Pariff or Parishes, which shall be allotted or exchanged by virtue of this, or the said recited Act j but that each and every Owner and Proprietor shall Hand and be seized of his, her, and their said Messuages, Cottages, Lands, and Tenements respectively, and of the Allotment and Allotments made in right or in respect thereof, and also of such other Messuages, Cottages, Lands or Tenements as shall be taken by him, her, or them in Exchange as aforesaid, to, for, and upon such and the same Uses, and for such and the fame Estates, and subject to such and the fame Wills, Deeds, Surrenders, Limitations, Remainders, Powers, and Provisoes, Charges, Debts, and Incumbrances, and no other, as the Messuages, Cottages, Lands, or Tenements, whereof such Owners and Proprietors were respectively seized or possessed at or immediately before the Execution of the said Award, or for which, or for or in respect whereof such Allotments or Exchanges shall be made, would have been subject to, charged with, or affected by, in case this Act had not been made.

XLVI. And be it further enacted, That once at least in each and every Year, during the Execution of this Act, (such Year to be computed from the Day of the passing thereof) the said Commissioners shall, and they are hereby required to make a just and true Account or Statement of all Sums of Money by them received and expended, or due to them for their Trouble and Expences in the Execution of the said recited Act and this Act; and such Account or Statement when so made, together with the Vouchers relating thereto, shall be by them laid before any One or more of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace acting in and for the said County of Norfolk, to be by him or them examined and balanced, and such Balance shall be by such Justice or Justices stated in the Book ot Accounts to be kept in the Office of the Clerk to the said Commissioners and no Charge or Item in such Account or Statement shall be binding upon the Parties concerned, or valid in Law, unless the same shall have been duly allowed by such Justice or Justices.
